1995tobiasdiez5037600closed2016-09-16T10:10:39Z2016-09-19T20:58:29ZFix search mixed from contains and grammar<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: As observed by @oscargus in https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/1876#issuecomment-247533268 certain mixed search queries does not work (for example
column2: `fruity and keywords=apple`).

column1: This PR fixes this issue.
Side-effect: simple queries as `fruity` are also recognized as ""grammar based"" (which is why I had to change a few tests). However
column2: there should be no major performance decline since the query parsing is quite fast and for the actual search in the end the same code gets called.

2010chriba15333371closed2016-09-19T18:14:38Z2016-09-22T05:38:03ZRewrite localization scriptRelevant Issues: #1939
I rewrote the the localization script:
The Script has following commands available
- `$ python scripts/syncLang.py status [--extended]`
- prints the current status to the terminal
- `[--extended]` if the translations keys which create problems should be printed
- usable with Gradle tasks
- `$ gradle status`
- `$ gradle statusExtended`
- `$ python scripts/syncLang.py markdown`
- Creates a markdown file of the current status and opens it
- usable with Gradle tasks
- `$ gradle statusWithMarkdown`
- `$ python scripts/syncLang.py update [--extended]`
- compares all the localization files against the English one and fixes unambiguous duplicates
column2: removes obsolete keys
column3: adds missing keys
column4: and sorts them

column1: - `[--extended]` if the translations keys which create problems should be printed
- usable with Gradle tasks
- `$ gradle update`
- `$ gradle updateExtended`

2039obraliar15609468closed2016-09-22T16:14:23Z2016-09-22T19:48:38Z[WIP] Hotfix for IndexOutOfBoundsException in MainTableHotfix `MainTable` using `Optional`.
Steps to reproduce the bug:
- Open two JabRef instances A and B
- Connect A and B to a shared database supporting LiveUpdate
- Create a new Entry in A
- Open the entry and change the value of a field like author
- Delete the new Entry from B and confirm the upcoming dialog in A
`MainTable` and `EntryMarker` contains a lot of ugly code which produces such errors and can be refactored. @bartsch-dev shows interest to do this probably in the next week. :+1:

2068tobiasdiez5037600closed2016-09-26T10:48:04Z2016-09-26T13:13:32ZRemove content selectors<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: This PR removes the ""content selectors"".
According to [our help page](http://help.jabref.org/en/ContentSelector)
column2: they are supposed ""to store a selection of often-used words or phrases that you use often in your database"". But exactly the same functionality is already there with the autocompletion. Thus I don't see any advantage of having the content selectors.

column1: I did some background check and was not able to find a single bib file in the web which uses the content selectors. Moreover
column2: the most discussions about them were from around 2004. The only feature request related to content selectors is the still open https://sourceforge.net/p/jabref/feature-requests/669/ which requests to store certain phrases that are often used in reviews.

column1: I kind of see the use case there
column2: but if this feature is really wished I would opt for a review template.

column1: To be honest
column2: I doubt that anybody even understood how to add phrases in the ""Manage content selector"" dialog
column3: not to mention that probably nobody looked under ""content selectors"" for such a feature.

column1: @JabRef/developers do you know of a good use case for this feature??
(will fix the localization stuff before merge)

2102lenhard1515701closed2016-09-30T09:47:14Z2016-10-03T07:37:47ZStore LaTeX-free fields in BibEntryBased on the discussion in #1993 and the work of @bartsch-dev in #2091
column2: this PR aims to improve the speed of search by storing LaTeX-free versions of field values in a cache. It aims at a balance between better performance and an acceptable memory footprint. Basically
column3: all ideas from #1993 are implemented: a cached store of LaTeX-free fields which is computed on demand
column4: String internalization
column5: and regex performance improvements in `LatexToUnicode`.

column1: Here are measurements with the new branch:
Benchmark                             Mode  Cnt         Score        Error  Unit
Benchmarks.latexToUnicodeConversion  thrpt   20    119823.078   2063.425  ops/s
Benchmarks.parallelSearch            thrpt   20       735.890    113.685  ops/s
Benchmarks.search                    thrpt   20       397.807     28.557  ops/s
The memory footprint of a database with 6500 entries is ~ 912 MB on my machine
And on current master:
Benchmark                             Mode  Cnt         Score        Error  Unit
Benchmarks.latexToUnicodeConversion  thrpt   20     94367.718   2570.784  ops/s
Benchmarks.parallelSearch            thrpt   20        58.204       3.285  ops/s
Benchmarks.search                    thrpt   20        30.531       0.952  ops/s
The memory footprint of the same 6500 entry database is ~ 888 MB.
All in all
column2: this looks like a hefty performance improvement at little memory cost.

2118obraliar15609468closed2016-10-04T23:06:38Z2016-10-14T11:11:54ZImplementation of autosave & backup featureRelated to: https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/344.
**Utility for local databases:**

This feature is event based and saves the database if activated on every user interaction. An intelligent `ExecutorService` and `workerQueue` are preventing a high load while saving. Furthermore all redundant save tasks will be rejected.
An event based `BackupManager` replaces the old time based backup system. This one is also using a
`ExecutorService` to prevent high load issues.
**Utility for shared databases:**
For shared databases this feature actually synchronizes the local file which is associated with the shared database supporting LiveUpdate!

This PR replaces the latter with former. Additionally
column2: `ParseException` is moved from `model` to the exact same place of `ParserException`. Its prior position in `model` was architecturally misplaced and its usages in `model` have been replaced with `IllegalArgumentException`

2125chriba15333371closed2016-10-05T17:50:37Z2016-10-07T15:34:52ZFix entry preview not updated properlyFixes: #2105.
### Steps to reproduce:
1. have at least 2 entries
2. open the entry editor and close it
- the preview will be rendered correctly
3. select the other entry
- the preview will be rendered correctly
4. select the first entry (the one you opened the editor with)
5. the preview will not be updated
The problem is that the editor variable doesn't get cleared when the editor closes
column2: thus the bottom component in the main table doesn't get updated if that entry is the last one which had the editor open.

column2: so I invested some time in it. It integrates the changes from #1964 and turns the different special fields into enum values. column2: highlighting was done manually by adding tags to matches in the html text being sent to the pane. Instead

column2: why

column1: # Integration of the recommendersystem Mr. DLib
## Reason for pull request
We from Mr. DLib would like to integrate a recommendation system into JabRef. We believe that both sides will benefit from this.
This pull request is the basis for further and deeper discussion of what is the right way to implement this feature.
## Changes made to JabRef

A new tab in the EntryEditor is added on the very right with a small MDL icon. A loading screen is shown in this tab while a Thread makes a request to the RESTful webservice of Mr. DLib. With the received response
column2: a SAX parser parses the XML the response contains. Currently the html-code inside this XML is taken to display the six recommendations received from the server.

column1: If you want to have a look how the XML delivered by the server please click the following link: https://api-dev.mr-dlib.org/v1/documents/gesis-smarth-0000003299/related_documents/
## Notes
Please note
column2: that this is only an example recommendations
column3: the server-structure for handling the request is in implementation. Once this done
column4: the title of the selected Item represents the request and based on this MR DLib will respond with matching articles.

column1: Please note
column2: that the appearance is only a suggestion. We are open and pleased for further input.

column1: Please note
column2: that code style is up to change. If you have improvements
column3: they are all welcome.

column1: A bug i couldn't deal with is
column2: that the new ""Related Articles"" tab I created is only called up to 5 times.  After that it don't get updated. It would be very helpful if someone could give me a hint where I have a mistake in my mental model of JabRef.

2195chriba15333371closed2016-10-25T22:41:31Z2016-10-30T17:48:24ZEnable version checker to recognize alpha/beta buildsThe Update checker is now able to handle alpha/beta builds.
The alpha/beta Tag has to be appended after the version number with a prepended `-` (eg. `3.7-alpha`

I also suggest that the `dev` tag gets prepended by a `-` to make it easier to read (especially if its a pre-stable version (eg. `3.7-alpha-dev--snapshot...`)). Currently this isn't necessary but it is supported.
The versionchecker only suggest non-stable builds if the currently installed version is also not stable (that's why I need to grab all the available versions now).

2230matthiasgeiger676652closed2016-11-03T14:16:38Z2016-11-04T08:56:56ZFix maintable sortingFixes #2200 by using the latex free value of the field for sorting the main table.
However
column2: just using `getLatexFreeField()` was not possible as the table is using `getFieldOrAlias`. Thus I introduced a new method `getFieldOrAliasLatexFree()` which is based on the previous implementation of `getFieldOrAlias()` using lambdas. This approach is used instead of formatting the `getFieldOrAlias()` result for performance reasons as the latex-free field values are cached in the `BibEntry`.

column1: *Sidenote: If this approach is approved by you
column2: the same should be applied to `BibDatabase.getResolvedFields()` which is used in `MainTableColumn.getColumnValue()` to show a latex-free version of the contents in the main table)*

column1: 2250shitikanth544054closed2016-11-08T10:23:05Z2016-12-05T17:36:21Z[WIP] Use v8 engine for CSL"Changes made:
- Added a compile dependency on com.eclipsesource.j2v8 in build.gradle
We are using citeproc-java library in CitationStyleGenerator to generate previews
column2: which itself is basically a wrapper around the javascript library citeproc-js. Switching to V8 engine dramatically improves the time taken to generate these previews. For example
column3: on my laptop
column4: generating preview used to take about 20s for the first preview
column5: and 10s for each subsequent preview; using V8 reduces both by a factor of 10.

column2: then the file is first downloaded and afterwards imported as usual. This functionality will enable JabFox to pass PDFs directly to JabRef for importing.

column1: Further changes:

- [Changed](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/compare/master...tobiasdiez:commandLine?expand=1#diff-e415888225bbbeb20a948c9ff07de910R278) the log level for parser errors. `ImportFormatReader.importUnknownFormat` first tries to open the file as a bib-file and thus this logging resulted in many log-entries if the file is not in the BibTeX format.
- Fixed an NPE which occurred when the ParserResult of the imported file had no path attached.

2281tobiasdiez5037600closed2016-11-17T14:32:16Z2016-11-18T16:56:51ZFix #2279: File permissions are kept upon saveFixes #2279.

JabRef does not directly writes to the bib-file upon save but creates a temporary file which is then copied over the original one. In this process the original file permissions get lost. Should be fixed with this PR (I have not tried it...).
I pushed the code to the branch https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/tree/filePermissions but for some reason the setup files do not show up on [builds.jabref.org](http://builds.jabref.org/)

2303matthiasgeiger676652closed2016-11-21T08:13:49Z2016-11-21T13:01:11ZUpdate citeproc dependency to 1.0.1see https://github.com/michel-kraemer/citeproc-java/releases1003422

2304lenhard1515701closed2016-11-21T17:20:06Z2016-12-02T12:35:10ZReplace usage of Threads and priorities with thread pool"The current priority-based thread handling in JabRef is bad for two reasons:
- Using and managing threads directly is bad practice. Since Java 1.6
column2: there is `ExecutorServices` for this.

column1: - Relying on thread priorities is highly JVM-dependent and not portable. It is quite pointless for us to do this.

This PR replaces the manual thread-handling with a second thread pool for all threads that were low-priority before. The main (only) difference to other JabRef threads is that low-priority threads sometimes run forever and need to be interrupted when JabRef should shut down. The new structure keeps this.

**Future tracking of SnapCraft at https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3121**

This outlines how we could get into the app store of Ubuntu (https://developer.ubuntu.com/en/desktop/ and https://shop.canonical.com/index.php?cPath=19). The issue is that snap is only supported in Ubuntu 16.04 LTS. <s>Thus
column2: this PR fails. We have to interpret following gist https://gist.github.com/evandandrea/c754964bfdfb176844f26f605ebbb8db and try to adapt it.

column1: It seems that the IRC channel is the only help out there. The gradle support is very new (see https://github.com/snapcore/snapcraft/pull/912).
Is there some Linuxer out there who wants to take over?</s>
## Howto install and update
- `snap install jabref --edge --devmode`
- `snap refresh jabref --edge --devmode`
## Current state
[![Snap Status](https://build.snapcraft.io/badge/JabRef/jabref.svg)](https://build.snapcraft.io/user/JabRef/jabref)
- Registered at https://build.snapcraft.io/user/koppor

- <s>Travis is used for building as currently only CircleCI 2.0 is supported for building and we use CircleCI 1.0 for building. A switch to CircleCI 2.0 is tested at branch [circleci20](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/tree/circleci20)
column2: but does currently not work and it does not seem to be easy to get it running</s>

column1: - <s>build takes approx. 9:30min</s>
- build will take place at `master` branch only (currently `snapcraft` only) to avoid much too much development versions at Ubuntu.
- [x] too long version strings (as we use) seem to be forbidden
column2: we just use `4.0-dev`.

column1: - [x] get initial `snapcraft.yaml` working
- [x] publish edge version to Ubuntu's snap repository: https://dashboard.snapcraft.io/dev/snaps/7999/
- [ ] publish stable version to Ubuntu's snap repository (https://uappexplorer.com/snaps) (currently no version visible) - has to be done manually
- [x] test at Ubuntu 16.04
- [x] <s>Get travis to work</s>
- <s>Blocked by https://forum.snapcraft.io/t/proxy-errors-on-large-uploads/1228</s>
- <s>solved by uploading one build at a time</s>
- [x] Icon in 256x256 for https://dashboard.snapcraft.io/dev/snaps/7999/update/?step=displaying

- [x] `javafx warning: WARNING: Loading FXML document with JavaFX API of version 8.0.112 by JavaFX runtime of version 8.0.111` - we cannot do anything about that: openjfx is [version 8.0.111 in Ubuntu Zetsy](https://packages.ubuntu.com/de/zesty/openjfx).
- [ ] <s>work on transfer to https://code.launchpad.net/~jabref/+snaps for allowing building on ubuntu instead of build on travis</s>
- [ ] gradle binary cannot be downloaded from http://build.snapcraft.io. See: https://github.com/canonical-websites/build.snapcraft.io/issues/918
## Steps after merging
- [ ] <s>adapt `travis.yml` to build snap only at the `master` branch (and not `snapcraft`).</s>
## Howto build locally
1. `docker run -it -v /d/git-repositories/jabref/jabref:/tmp/snap koppor/docker-snapcraft-java-de bash`
2. `cd /tmp/jabref`
3. Read along at https://snapcraft.io/docs/build-snaps/publish
## References
- http://snapcraft.io/docs/build-snaps/metadata
- https://snapcraft.io/docs/build-snaps/publish
- https://wiki.ubuntu.com/snapcraft/parts"181145315

2363chriba15333371closed2016-12-11T15:48:48Z2016-12-15T12:03:54ZAdd option to export citations to the clipboardNow the user can copy citations of multiple entries to the clipboard (with different outputformts).
### Steps:
- select (multiple) entries
- open the contextmenu
- Copy...
- Copy Citation...
- Select the desired ouputformat
- After a short freeze the ouput is in the clipboard
![copycitationtoclipboard](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15333371/21081140/e1b311d2-bfc0-11e6-94c9-25f60013fef9.png)
I implemented all outputformats implemented in the citeproc library (https://michel-kraemer.github.io/citeproc-java/using/output-formats/).
Since most styles use an increasing number in the citation I cannot use the CitationStyleCache here (b/c there it is always 1).

2364koppor1366654closed2016-12-11T17:37:55Z2016-12-16T14:36:12ZBe more friendly when using journal alias fieldI'd like to copy bibtex entries to biblatex databases and vice versa. When using required fields only
column2: this works perfectly. When in biblatex mode
column3: JabRef does not display the value of `journal` in the required fields
column4: because JabRef demands the field `journaltitle`. This is not only confusing for me
column5: but also for other users: #2209.

column1: I know that a clean solution is #521. This
column2: however
column3: won't happen this year.

column1: I also know that a bibtex-to-biblatex converter and biblatex-to-bibtex converter is another solution. This
column2: however
column3: forces users to run these when copying and pasting between databases. This could be solved by running these converters silently when copying and pasting. When JabRef is used in parallel to other software (such as Notepad++)
column4: this does not help. I cannot force everyone to use JabRef. Thus
column5: simply supporting `journal` in JabRef is the solution for me.

column1: The biblatex manual states:
> journal field (literal)
> An alias for journaltitle
column2: provided for BibTeX compatibility. See § 2.2.2.

column1: Thus
column2: it is not deprecated
column3: but an alias and should IMHO be considered as full alternative for `journaltitle`.

column1: <s>I am aware that this patch makes it hard for users using full biblatex with `journaltitle` instead of `journal`. I am assuming that not much users are aware of the different modes of JabRef and that they switch back and forth for the same file or for the bibentries.</s>
We now show both `journaltitle` and `journal` if these fields exists in as required fields.
This whole discussion somehow refs https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/160
* Minor improvement: Enhanced integrity checks testing for biblatex-only fields to be aware of more fields (e.g.
column2: `location`).

column1: * All fetchers return now bibtex. (Before: ArXiv and msbib created biblatex)

2368stefan-kolb2141507closed2016-12-12T13:55:46Z2016-12-17T17:56:38ZNever manually set ID of a BibEntry"The internal ID of a BibEntry should never be set manually. Closes #1721
DONE:
- Removed constructors that allow setting the ID of an entry
- __Every__ BibEntry now gets an ID on creation
- A clone of a BibEntry __always gets a unique ID__ now
- Only option to change ID of an entry is now via `setID()`
PENDING:
- [ ] Is IDGenerator really global and consistent between calls now?
- [ ] Can we import Bibentries without an open Database? See c884745. Importers used a static ID value before. Not 100% sure if this change has any side effects.

2369arnobl1052622closed2016-12-12T13:57:28Z2016-12-15T11:50:34ZRemove four Blob listeners"Hi guys
Sorry in advance for the long text.
We are researchers in software engineering that currently work on user interface (UI) bad coding practices. We are studying UI listeners
column2: in particular listeners that manage several widgets
column3: like the following listener extracted from JabRef:

column1: public void valueChanged(ListSelectionEvent evt) {
Object source = evt.getSource();
if (familyList.equals(source)) {
String family = familyList.getSelectedValue();
if (family != null) {
familyField.setText(family);
} else if (sizeList.equals(source)) {
String size = sizeList.getSelectedValue();
if (size != null) {
sizeField.setText(size);
} else if (styleList.equals(source)) {
String style = styleList.getSelectedValue();
if (style != null) {
styleField.setText(style);
updatePreview();
In such listeners
column2: the source widget is identified using if/switch statements. Thanks to empirical studies we have indications that such a practice has a negative impact on the code quality. We call UI listeners that control three or more widgets
column3: Blob Listeners (see this PDF document for more details: https://hal.inria.fr/hal-01308625v2/document).

column1: We identified in JabRef six instances of the Blob listener and for four of them we have a refactoring solution. This pull request (PR) removes these four Blob listeners by splitting them into atomic UI listeners (i.e. they manage a single widget). Each commit of this PR refers to one or two Blob listeners. We manually tested JabRef for any regression. The new code is less complex in terms of cyclomatic complexity (CC) and lines of code (LoC): the new code has -38 LoCs and -21 of CC on the refactored files (according to Sonar analyses).
Complementary to this PR
column2: we have several questions for the JabRef's developers:

column1: 1/ Do you think that coding UI listeners that manage several widgets is a bad coding practice?
2/ Do you think that the threshold of three or more widgets per listener relevant for characterising a Blob listener?
3/ Do you think that the refactored code relevant to remove Blob listeners?
4/ Do you have any idea of the reason of the presence of Blob listeners in your code?
For example
column2: lack of programming experience? Lack of anonymous functions (aka lambdas) in Java 7 (and previous JDKs)?

2388koppor1366654closed2016-12-16T06:27:07Z2016-12-16T11:36:45ZRename ""XMP data"" to ""XMP-metadata""""I worked with the ""import inspection dialog""
column2: which offers to offer entry-creation based on XMP meta data (refs #938). The dialog renders as follows:

column1: ![grabbed_20161216-072757](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1366654/21253754/34de5c92-c361-11e6-80dd-d987519a9405.png)
My issue is that is uses both ""XMP data"" and ""XMP-metadata"" for the same thing. I wanted to rename ""XMP-metadata"" to ""XMP data""
column2: but ""XMP-metadata"" appears in JabRef much more often. Thus
column3: I decided to keep ""XMP-metadata"" and just adapt two other strings to that writing.

column1: New rendering:
![grabbed_20161216-072851](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1366654/21253772/5382e5f0-c361-11e6-95d1-2ac102723e59.png)
Discussion: Maybe
column2: we should use ""XMP metadata"" (without dash) or even ""XMP meta data""."001919119

column2: link the files for the entry being edited instead of looking for the selected entries""Bug fix for issue number 2391.

column1: When clicking on ""Get fulltext"" from the editor view
column2: the autoSetLinks function should be performed only to the entry being edited.

column1: Before this pr
column2: the autoSetLinks function uses the selected entries
column3: which can causes problems in different cases (See issue number #2391 for details).

2396koppor1366654closed2016-12-17T21:26:47Z2016-12-18T12:35:01Z[WIP] Introduce explicit list of ALL_BIBLATEX_ONLY_FIELDSThis fixes #2390. The last implementation used `EntryConverter.FIELD_ALIASES_LTX_TO_TEX`. This implementation is based on `BibtexEntryTypes` and `BiblatexEntryTypes`.
## Issue
`JabRefPreferences.CUSTOM_TAB_NAME_num_` should be used to really determine the fields to check. This
column2: however
column3: is really a **huge** architectural rework.

column1: It has to be checked
column2: in following (seldom) situation:

column1: - Field X is defined in JabRef's BiblatexEntryTypes
- Field X is added by the user to a general tab
JabRef now complains that X is Biblatex only.
## Further changes
* ISBN and ISBN are now BibTeX fields
column2: too.

column1: - Reason: Even though
column2: both are not listed in [WikiPedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BibTeX) and the [lncs style](ftp://ftp.springer.de/pub/tex/latex/llncs/latex2e/splncs03.bst)
column3: I see them so hard tied to a book and article
column4: that I would add it. In the case of a DOI
column5: JabRef (more or less) enforces it by offering that field in the ""General"" tab. Moreover
column6: [it is part of plainnat.bst](http://tex.stackexchange.com/a/52046/9075) and [natbib](https://www.ctan.org/pkg/natbib) is a popular package.

column1: * `FieldName.COMMENT` instead of `FieldName.COMMENTS` (affects OaiImporter only)
* Preferences: Use FieldName constants at `setLanguageDependentDefaultValues()`

2398koppor1366654closed2016-12-18T14:16:44Z2016-12-18T22:24:37ZImprove CSL copyWhen copying citations to the clipboard using HTML (introduced by #2363)
column2: pasting into Nodepad++ leads to pure HTML be pasted. We had a short discussion during #2363 what would be more useful: HTML code or Text. I think
column3: text is better.

column1: When using ""Copy as Text"" offered by using the CSL library
column2: following is the text reaching Nodepad++:

column1: > 1.Garcia-Molina
column2: H.
column3: Salem
column4: K.: Sagas. In: Dayal
column5: U. and Traiger
column6: I.L. (eds.) SIGMOD’87: Proceedings of the Association for Computing Machinery Special Interest Group on Management of Data 1987 Annual Conference. pp. 249–259 ACM Press (1987).

column1: When using the results of this PR and using Copy as HTML:
> 1. Garcia-Molina
column2: H.
column3: Salem
column4: K.: Sagas. In: Dayal
column5: U. and Traiger
column6: I.L. (eds.) SIGMOD’87: Proceedings of the Association for Computing Machinery Special Interest Group on Management of Data 1987 Annual Conference. pp. 249–259 ACM Press (1987).

column1: Note the space after ""1."". Further
column2: when copying the entry preview generated by JabRef's internal mechanism (and not CSL)
column3: plain text is also pasted into Notepad++ instead of HTML. Thus
column4: this PR makes the behavior consistent. Further
column5: with this PR
column6: html entities are correctly converted to text. - I know that I could contact upstream and let CSL correctly create a text citation and then update JabRef to kick-off two conversons: HTML and Text using CSL. This
column7: however
column8: is IMHO more effort than ""just"" (more or less) correctly converting HTML to Text within JabRef.

column1: Continuation of https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/1438 (for some reason github didn't let me reopen it
column2: thus a new PR).

column1: The core functionality now works
column2: that is:

column1: - show groups tree
- filter entries when a group is selected
- show number of entries (well
column2: not really ""core"" but works nonetheless)

column1: I tested it with a big db and the performance was quite good.
Of course
column2: many features of the original dialog are still missing. But I think it is better to merge/rework the group pane peu à peu instead of a big un-reviewable PR. Also feedback about the design is welcome (this is just a proposal). [Builds are available](http://builds.jabref.org/groupsRework/) since I learned how to push to master 😄 .

column1: Discussion: There is no [merge entries](https://help.jabref.org/en/MergeEntries) dialog shown. The title by the publisher is always used. I would say that this is OK as the title casing of the publisher should take precedence. If the user wants to overwrite it
column2: he has to use the entry editor and paste the title again in the title field.

209032
2420lenhard1515701closed2016-12-22T10:05:38Z2016-12-22T10:15:10ZRemove the redundant worker interfaceThis is a refactoring PR (yeah
column2: I know we do not really want pure refactoring PRs for now)
column3: and it is open for discussion (I will not throw a tantrum if it does not get merged).

column1: I ran into the `Worker` interface
column2: which does really nothing but extend the `Runnable` interface. I fail to see the point in this additional level of indirection. The `Worker` interface is supposed to mark tasks that should not be executed on the EDT
column3: but there is nothing in the interface to actually maintain that apart from a comment line. All code using the `Worker` depends on the object being a `Runnable`
column4: the `Worker` aspect is basically ignored
column5: as there is nothing to consider in the first place.

column1: Instead
column2: there is class `AbstractWorker` which implements the `Worker` aka `Runnable` interface and actually does provide the support for executing the task off the EDT. `AbstractWorker` is the class that is actually used in most of the code and it works just as fine if you have it implement `Runnable` directly.

column1: Therefore
column2: in the spirit of science
column3: I suggest to apply Occam's razor and to use the simplest solution (remove the additional indirection of `Worker`).

2435simonharrer375693closed2016-12-27T12:57:24Z2017-02-15T12:43:16ZDetect unused journals by checking whether there are abbreviations fo……r the journals available.
I have 500 bibtex entries
column2: out of which 125 are journal articles. With the article bibtex type
column3: there are a few issues:

column1: - It happens that an article should actually have the inproceedings type
column2: but Google Scholar generated it wrong
column3: and it was not corrected and checked.

column1: - That the known journal is misspelled. This is hard to detect manually.
As a solution
column2: I propose to use an integrity check which displays all the articles which have journals that are not in the abbreviation repository. This has helped me to determine misspellings
column3: wrongly classified articles
column4: and improve the abbreviations list overall as well.

column1: This integrity check would also advertise our journal abbreviation feature more
column2: and encourage people to contribute to journal abbreviations lists. Maybe
column3: we should really create a cloud based service for that?

2445lenhard1515701closed2017-01-02T16:17:27Z2017-01-05T21:26:24ZEscaping of escape symbols in the MetaDataFixes #2426 and is ready for review.
# Old discussion
Attempts to fix  #2426.
Is not yet functional
column2: since the issue goes somewhat deeper and affects LaTeX-encoding things in all MetaData
column3: also groups. The problem is line 64 in MetaDataSerializer:

column1: stringBuilder.append(StringUtil.quote(dataItem
column2: MetaData.SEPARATOR_STRING
column3: MetaData.ESCAPE_CHARACTER)).append(MetaData.SEPARATOR_STRING);

column1: For every MetaData item
column2: all special characters are quoted
column3: including the quoting symbol (`\`). Thus
column4: if there is a `\` in the MetaData
column5: it is quoted during serialization
column6: resulting in `\\`
column7: which is read as such and requoted on the next serialization

column1: Unfortunately
column2: unquoting the text during parsing and quoting it again during writing does not help
column3: since a single `\` will simply be lost. E.g.: unquoting `\""U` would result in `""U`
column4: which upon quoting anew would stay `""U`.

column1: The same problem should occur for groups
column2: if I am not mistaken.

column1: I now have the following options to resolve the problem:
1. Add special handling for content selectors to avoid quoting for them
2. Change `StringUtil.quote` to avoid quoting the quoting char (`\`)
3. Add another method in StringUtil that avoids quoting the quoting char and use it for MetaData in general.
I am afraid that changing `StringUtil.quote` has wider implications that I am not aware of.
column2: especially relating to groups Hence
column3: there is a need for discussion.

2464lenhard1515701closed2017-01-13T16:09:35Z2017-01-15T12:06:57ZFix conversion of ""'n"" and ""\'{n}"" from LaTeX to Unicode""This is a follow up for fixing  #2458
The combinations `\'n` and `\\'{n}` are converted from LaTeX to different symbols in Unicode.
This was really hard to track down. It was not a problem in our conversion maps
column2: but in `LatexToUnicode`. The ultimate reason is that this code is just an utter mess of hacks and I could only fix this by adding another ugly map on top of this heap.

column1: We have already identified this class to cause performance issues and
column2: as you can see here
column3: it is very difficult to maintain. We should consider removing the functionality and rewriting it from scratch or (preferably) replace it with an external library. After all
column4: converting a LaTeX string to Unicode seems sufficiently well-defined that there is some library for this out there.

2474tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-01-20T14:40:05Z2017-08-18T18:01:30Z[WIP] Use CERMINE as PDF parser<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: This PR replaces our own PDF parser with [CERMINE](https://github.com/CeON/CERMINE).
In my tests
column2: this library was able to extract (relatively) correct information from a wide variety of articles. It had some problems with books and thesises (what is the plural of a thesis?) through.

column1: As far as I understand it
column2: it uses neural networks that try to analyze the PDF on a structural level (e.g. the title is often placed rather prominently). More information can be found in a [paper](http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10032-015-0249-8).

column1: In summary:
Pros:
- Good detection level
- Works for a lot of different journals
- OpenSource and actively developed

- Provides facilities to extract bibliographic information from a citation string (i.e. plain text to BibEntry converter would be possible). Can be tested [online](http://adalab.icm.edu.pl/api/citation_parser.html?q=L.+Bolikowski%2C+N.+Houssos%2C+P.+Manghi%2C+J.+Schirrwagen%2C+%22Data+as+First-class+Citizens%2C%22+D-Lib+Magazine%2C+vol.+21%2C+no.+1%2F2%2C+2015.)

- Also extracts document structure (i.e. sections) and a list of referenced articles! See for [example](https://pub.phyks.me/paper_references_extractor/cermine_out/4945dbf177156d481f686f116b9fce5b.pdf.cermine.xml)
Cons:
- Has problems with books/thesis
- Increases the size of JabRef from around 40 mb to 70 mb.
A comparison of different metadata extract tools can be found in the [following blog post](https://known.phyks.me/2016/comparison-of-tools-to-fetch-references-for-scientific-papers)
column2: which ends with the following summary

column1: > the machine learning based models (Cermine and Grobid) seems to give far better results than the simple approach taken by pdfextract
column2: at the expense of being more difficult to build and run. Cermine gives a bunch of infos
column3: too much in my opinion
column4: and I think Grobid is given the most reusable and complete results.

column1: I tried to include [Grobid](https://github.com/kermitt2/grobid) but it appears to be [hard to use](https://github.com/kermitt2/grobid/issues/59) and has some [problems on Windows (until recently?)](https://github.com/kermitt2/grobid/issues/92).
@koppor I added you as reviewer since you wrote the PdfImporter as far as I understood it.

2499lenhard1515701closed2017-01-30T11:02:31Z2017-01-30T12:16:23ZDisplay LaTeX-free version of field content in entry preview panelFixes #2498.

The PR implements a new method in `BibEntry`: `getResolvedFieldOrAliasLatexFree` that builds upon our existing `LatexFree` methods and extends this functionality to resolved fields. This method can be reused in the UI parts of JabRef that should rather display a Unicode version of a field than a LaTeX version
column2: such as the entry preview.

column1: 2563tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-02-17T16:42:17Z2017-02-23T16:35:57ZMake automatic groups a first-class citizien"<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: So after you guys had your fun in Lugano (and harvested a big number of changed lines)
column2: I want to have my share too. Thus here I'm with a new groups-related PR.

column1: Previously there was the option to automatically generate a bunch of groups. For example based on the keywords contained in a certain field. However
column2: this process was a one-time thing
column3: which means that once the groups were created they were not keep in sync with changes to the entries.

column1: In this PR
column2: I introduce the automatic groups as a new type of groups that based on a certain criteria automatically create subgroups and keep them synchronized with the changes.

column1: The current implementation has a few caveats which I would like to address in a new PR:
- Automatic groups are not yet written to the bib file (and parsed).
- The update process only happens if you switch between databases and the groups tree is reinitialized.
- The UI in the groups edit dialog is probably not the greatest...
Remark: Our architecture tests threw a NPE instead of a meaningful message in case of an issue. This is also fixed.

2586tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-02-23T16:11:48Z2017-03-16T22:15:53ZFixes #2571 and another unhandled exception"<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: Fix two unhandled exceptions:
- StringIndexOutOfBoundsException reported in the [forum](http://discourse.jabref.org/t/jabref-not-opening/476/3)
column2: easy fix by https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/compare/fixExcept?expand=1#diff-224c7e1325d710cbdcb0995525549d30R1492

column1: - IllegalArgumentException #2571 Reason was that the writing code threw a IllegalArgumentException when the field content contains unbalanced braces (i.e. `title = {some text containing { }`). However
column2: IllegalArgumentException is a runtime exception and so it was easy to miss that one should catch this exception properly. Fixed by introducing the checked exception InvalidFieldValueException.

column1: In the longer term
column2: we should probably replace this check completely by the integrity checker.

2634tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-03-12T12:38:31Z2017-03-16T15:48:38ZFinally write the new group properties to the bib file: icon with color, description, expanded status and automatic groups<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: Serialize and parse:
- Icon (with customizable color) that is shown in the groups panel (implements a [feature request in the forum](http://discourse.jabref.org/t/assign-colors-to-groups/321)).

- Description text that is shown on mouse hover (implements old feature requests [489](https://sourceforge.net/p/jabref/feature-requests/489/) and [818](https://sourceforge.net/p/jabref/feature-requests/818/))

- ""automatic groups"" that automatically create subgroups based on a certain criteria (e.g. a subgroup for every author or keyword). Implements [91](https://sourceforge.net/p/jabref/feature-requests/91/)
column2: [398](https://sourceforge.net/p/jabref/feature-requests/398/) and [#1173](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/1173).

column1: - Expansion status [#1428](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/1428)
While implementing these changes
column2: I had to introduce a new ""StaticGroup"" label in the bib file that replaces the old ""ExplicitGroup"". The problem was that the old group with legacy bib references

column1: ExplicitGroup:StaticGroup\;0\;1137631\;1233448\;1314293\;;
otherwise couldn't be distinguished from a new explicit group with icon and color:
StaticGroup:StaticGroup\;0\;expansion\;icon\;color\;description\;;
I think we really should switch to https://github.com/koppor/jabref/issues/232 at some point.

2636tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-03-12T19:07:48Z2017-03-13T11:34:28ZImprove perfomance of opening a database that still used the old groups format<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: Previously
column2: the conversion of the old groups format to the new one was performed after the database was completely loaded and displayed. Thus after every change during the conversion the groups panel and main table were redrawn
column3: resulting in performance problems (in particular with larger db's).

column1: Now the conversion is done before the db is displayed (and thus nobody yet listens to the changes).
Fixes: http://discourse.jabref.org/t/v3-8-2-x64-windows-problem-saving-large-bib-libraries/456

2650tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-03-15T21:29:09Z2017-03-31T12:35:17ZPerformance improvements related to import<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: Adding a larger number of entries (e.g. after ""Web search"" or import) currently takes very long. This PR tries to remove some overhead: add `insertEntries` method that admits many entries as arguments so that events are only fired once (and not after every entry).
The performance is better with these changes but still not good enough (importing something into a very huge db leads to JabRef not responding).
Moreover
column2: instead of creating many threads for the computation of the ""hit number"" in the groups panel
column3: a thread pool is used.

column1: 2663RolfStarre5969100closed2017-03-17T21:56:56Z2017-08-10T16:04:53Z[WIP] Testing bibtex key patterns and fixing title_case/capitalize modifiers"<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: Related to https://github.com/koppor/jabref/issues/237
I'm working on adding tests for key patterns + key patterns in combination with modifiers.
I found out why the title_case and capitalize modifiers didn't work with shorttitle. It went wrong because before the modifier was applied the shorttitle was already a concatenated string
column2: so the formatter would just see it as a single word.

column1: For example if we have the title ""An Awesome Paper on JabRef""
column2: it would first turn into ""AnAwesomePaper""
column3: and then the modifier would turn it into ""Anawesomepaper"".

2681tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-03-23T16:27:31Z2017-03-24T09:53:59ZFix #2680 and fix #2667: Swing errors are catched properly and without freezingHopefully
column2: fixes that the error console is not updated properly #2667 as well as that Swing errors lead to frezzing #2680. At least for me
column3: it works now without problems. @stefan-kolb @lynyus can you please also check it.

column1: For the error console
column2: I took the suggestion https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/2667#issuecomment-288742546 by @matthiasgeiger. The freezing after a Swing message occurred since

column1: ̀`LOGGER.warn(""No localized message exception message defined. Falling back to getMessage()."");`
lead to recursive calls (actually
column2: Log4j has some logic to prevent deadlocks but these don't take effect since the original message is thrown in the Swing thread
column3: while the above ""no localized messsage"" is posted in the JavaFX thread.). I simply changed it to log level ""debug""
column4: which effectively hides it in most cases. As a positive side effect
column5: the scroll issue mentioned in https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/2667#issuecomment-288714639 is also fixed.

column2: why

column1: Since @lynyus wants to implement a fulltext pdf search 😛
column2: we need a proper way to display the results. In this PR a very plain PDF viewer is implemented. Most  #PDFs are displayed correctly
column3: maybe with a few small glitches here and there. Basic features like scrolling
column4: changing pages and zooming work. In addition
column5: while being in ""live mode"" the linked document of the currently selected BibEntry is shown - this is very handy in a two-display setup since one can have JabRef's maintable on one screen and the always-current PDF on the second.

2704tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-04-02T11:35:05Z2017-04-06T13:50:04ZWrite groups under tag `group` instead of `groupstree` to enhance compatibility with previous versionsRight now
column2: files written with 4.0 cannot be opened in older versions. The new format of the groups leads to a NPE.

column1: As a way out
column2: I changed the tag for the groups tree from `groupstree` to `group` (`groups` was already used by previous version way back). Thus older versions completely ignore the group tree and no longer try to parse it
column3: so no NPE is thrown. On the downside
column4: however
column5: the groups tree is deleted upon save in the older version. Still a bit better than a crashing Jabref in my opinion.

2707lenhard1515701closed2017-04-03T14:49:41Z2017-04-03T15:46:13ZMake sure that JavaFx shuts down in case another JabRef instance is a……lready open
Fixes #2698. The problem was that JavaFX requires `Platform.exit();` to be called on shutdown. Otherwise the JavaFX application thread does not terminate. In the case of this issue
column2: a GUI was never opened and therefore this statement was never reached. This should be mitigated now.

2711lenhard1515701closed2017-04-05T08:40:48Z2017-04-06T13:48:24ZAvoid conversion of single underscoresFixes #2664
Single underscores that are not followed by `{` are not converted to unicode during the LaTeX to unicode conversion. This is not actually correct according to the rules of LaTeX
column2: but seems to be an important exception required by our users.

column1: This is achieved by the following:
1. Replace all single underscores with `JABREFUNDERSCORE`
2. Do the unicode conversion
3. Replace `JABREFUNDERSCORE` with an underscore
TODO: We should find a better magic word instead of `JABREFUNDERSCORE`
column2: because every character will be processed by latex2unicode and that costs performance. However
column3: it should still be long and unique enough so that we avoid accidental conversions. Suggestions anyone?

2716lenhard1515701closed2017-04-06T13:27:23Z2017-04-16T16:32:34ZKeep unkwown meta dataAs discussed in #2704
column2: unkown meta data items were deleted so far. With this PR
column3: this is no longer the case. The only problem is that the formatting of meta data items is not parsed (and this would be a bigger thing)
column4: since so far we assumed full control over the meta data items. This version tries to keep formatting as far as possible
column5: but does a few customizations (escaping `;` and adding newlines where appropriate). The result is that you can rename a `groupstree` meta data item and it will be kept and formatted in the very same way
column6: also with a different name.

column1: I would say this is good enough and we adapt it when someone has a use case or problem.

column3: as this PR uncovers. Thus

- org.jabref.logic.journals.Abbreviation uses javafx.beans.property.SimpleStringProperty
- test/org.jabref.logic.l10n.LocalizationParser uses FXMLLoader/PlatformImpl
Although we might think about making exceptions for the beans and tests

column7: JabRef uses the '[auth]' part of the pattern and finds just the files with the matching author
column8: as expected. A relevant unit test was added; no other tests were broken.

2754tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-04-17T19:59:20Z2017-04-18T13:05:01ZEntry editor goes JavaFX<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: So now that we have released the beta version
column2: we can go back to the alpha state with this PR 😄.

column1: I actually just wanted to have a look at the autocompletion and use some built-in JavaFX functionality for it. However
column2: just changing the JTextarea's to their JavaFX equivalent wasn't possible since the editor components (additional buttons next to the text area) required JTextareas.

column1: Thus
column2: eating the foul egg (= Easter version of ""in den sauren Apfel beißen"")
column3: I started to migrate the whole entry editor to JavaFX. So far only the DOI component is re-implemented.

column1: Points to notice:
- Using JavaFX bindings
column2: there is no longer the need to manually update the entry after a changed happened. This should fix these nasty bugs that sometimes changes in the editor got lost when performing a different action. Moreover
column3: the main table is instantly updated with the changes in the editor.

column1: - I opted for a slightly different architecture. Previously
column2: there were the text field and additional components. Now these are combined into one FieldEditor.

column1: - As for the groups interface
column2: I will continue slowly to reimplement the other field editors.

column1: - The style is not that different from the Swing version. For the buttons
column2: I only used images:

column1: ![snipimage](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5037600/25102492/f8b61756-23b8-11e7-8024-e9ff48b132c5.JPG)

2768tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-04-19T13:43:50Z2017-04-20T12:52:25ZRemove preferences and globals from tests<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: This PR aims to make @lenhard happy again by introducing huge architectural constraints on our tests: they are not allowed to work with the preferences class anymore. As a positive side-effect also @koppor will be happy about this as tests now can no longer accidentally change or reset your preferences.
Changes in detail:
- Remove `JabRefPreferences.getInstance` or `Globals.prefs` by mocking away all preferences class (like `LayoutFormatterPreferences`)

- Refactor `KeyBindinings` and `JournalAbbreviations` so that these classes don't operate on the `JabRefPreferences` class anymore. This required to hide some methods of the preferences in a new interface
`PreferencesService`.
- Create architectural tests for the tests

column1: Another reimplementation of an editor to make JabRef usable again 😸
column2: this time featuring the date editor. The new one uses the built-in JavaFX date picker and so `LGoodDatePicker` is no longer needed.

column1: ![untitled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5037600/25298239/b19487e8-26f3-11e7-886c-43181503edee.png)
In the progress I discovered a quite hidden feature: when you double-clicked in a date field
column2: then the current date was inserted. I removed this as I think nobody really knew about it in the first place and moreover it also takes 2 clicks to select the current date with the calendar popup.

column1: There are still some layout problems (small width
column2: additional empty line below it) that are probably a result of the mixed Swing and JavaFX stuff. Hopefully
column3: this will be resolved more or less automatically if also the background tab pane is converted to JavaFX.

column1: The file editor now looks like this:

column2: I changed the behavior slightly to reduce the amount of popuped dialogs:

column1: - ""Add new file"" directly adds the linked file (and guesses the file type) instead of showing the ""edit linked file"" dialog
- ""Download from URL"" adds the download to the file list and showing a progress bar:
![filedownloadinprogress](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5037600/25431624/9963fc80-2a81-11e7-8685-1dec04b62b32.png)

- Files that are found by the ""Auto link"" feature are automatically added to the files list (but not serialized in the files field) and can be accepted (i.e. serialized) by clicking the accept button:
![fileautofound](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5037600/25431654/bf54b0a6-2a81-11e7-9bd5-0d9dc18e514a.png)
The code was ugly and is still not very nice (global dependencies everywhere). Maybe I will find the time later to refactor the code even more.
Some features are still missing (e.g. right-click menu).

2838LinusDietz1254003closed2017-05-12T16:20:04Z2018-07-02T21:53:38Z[WIP] Search in PDF FilesSo I had some time to implement the backend for the PDF Search using Apache Lucene. Now it is possible to perform queries for strings based on the content and the metadata of a linked PDF.
At the moment I provide the following API:
* Indexing
- `PdfIndexer.createIndex(BibDatabase database)` Adds all PDF files linked to an entry in the database to new Lucene search index.
- `PdfIndexer.addToIndex(BibEntry entry)` Adds all the pdf files linked to one entry in the database to an existing (or new) Lucene search index
- `PdfIndexer.flushIndex()` Deletes all entries from the Lucene search index.
* Searching
- `PdfSearchersearch(String searchString
column2: int maxHits)` Search for results matching a query in the Lucene search index.

column1: This returns an instance of  PdfSearchResults which has a `getSortedByScore()` method.
So please provide some feedback on this. If it is fine
column2: we can have a look how to design a front-end for this.

2875tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-05-30T20:53:20Z2017-05-31T08:13:36ZFix entry editor<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: Fixes #2843 and #2851.
This was a tricky bug: JavaFX creates empty dummy cells at the end of a list view. For some reason the list view for the linked files had an initial size of `1.7976931348623157E308` and
column2: well
column3: creating that many dummy cells takes a while (probably longer than the universe took to create humans) and eventually lead to a freeze of the JavaFX thread.

column1: The fix was easy
column2: just add `maxHeight=""100""` and be happy (finally
column3: after trying to debug the problem for ages).

column1: This PR improves the performance of the entry editor to a satisfactory level (switching between entries leads to a short flicker of the entry editor but no real delay). Things changed:
- Tab panel is converted to JavaFX
- Each tab is initialized only upon focus
Moreover
column2: a bit of the code was refactored (e.g. the creation of the different tabs is extracted from the EntryEditor class to many smaller classes
column3: one for each tab).

2914tilsche9112758closed2017-06-15T14:55:45Z2017-06-15T16:21:20Z[WIP] Avoid duplicate results for recursive search in RegExpBasedFileFinderThe `RegExpBasedFileFinder` found the exact same files multiple times because 1) ""**"" recursively walks through subdirectories and 2) `Files.find` was called with a high `maxDepth`. So the file was found once from the root directory
column2: and again from it's directory.

column1: The suggested change addresses this by not recursively searching with Files.find. I presume that it was not intended that search was recursive without `**`. This may be related to #2274.

column2: e.g. http://iopscience.iop.org/journal/2041-8205. (I have run `gradlew check` and there was no problem.)

The frequent events are due to the bidirectional binding which transfers every change directly into the BibEntry. If we want fewer events
column2: the only solution will probably be to break the binding
column3: which would be very disappointing for the JavaFX implementation. In my point of view the problem is not on the side of event creation. After all
column4: every change should trigger an event and JavaFX triggers many changes. Imho
column5: this should be fixed in how we react to events.

column1: I also noticed the exception
column2: but do not get a dialog. This seems to happen because of the save operation invoked by the backup.

column1: A solution might be to do less backups
column2: by:

column1: 1. Doing backups only every X events and not for every event
2. Ignoring FieldChangeEvents in the Backup
3. Adding the size of the field change in the FieldChangeEvent class
column2: so that you can ignore it if only 1 character changed.

column1: This PR combines options 1. and 3.
column2: i.e.: The backup manager ignores events that are very minor and only does a backup if enough of them have happened (currently set to five).

Changes in the entry editor now mark the database as dirty. This are somewhat proactive: even only opening the entry editor will mark the database as changed. I'd say this isn't a problem. I'd rather have it do the marking than forget one.

3004lenhard1515701closed2017-07-13T09:29:06Z2017-07-13T10:51:04ZOnly do a back up for bigger changes or if a different field is editedThis PR makes the BackupManager a little more intelligent. It fixes a bug that I've only noticed locally and discussed with @tobiasdiez in chat. There's no issue for it
column2: but the fix comes directly here.

column1: If you have save actions configured (say LatexToUnicode) and the backup triggers too early (say after 5 characters) then the BackupManager interrupts you if you add a longer command in the entry edior (say `\alpha`). With this PR
column2: the BackupManager is no longer triggered every five characters
column3: but only if there are changes of more than one character (a user pastes text into the entry editor) or if the user edits a different field than before. This seems way more reasonable to me and is as it has been before (only backups when a user changes the field
column4: edits a group
column5: etc.)

3009tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-07-13T15:58:57Z2017-07-13T19:54:26ZImprove performance of journal abbreviation loader<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: This PR improves the performance of the journal abbreviation loader/repository/parser and thus is a partial fix for https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/2966.
Previously
column2: loading and parsing the journal repository files took nearly 10 seconds and now almost nothing:

column1: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5037600/28175332-3b59e1da-67f4-11e7-9560-f2a504205c0a.png)
Main boost came from using `equalsIgnoreCase` instead of using `equals(text.toLowerCase())` and changing `LinkedList` to `HashSet` as we don't care about the ordering.
I had to adopt two tests which relied on the sorting.
Moreover
column2: only one copy of the list is now stored in memory opposed to the 1 + 4 maps previously (equates to 1/10 RAM consummation). In principle
column3: this makes the journal auto completion slower but I couldn't notice any negative impact.

column1: I just remembered that my initial motivation to convert the entry editor to JavaFX came from my desire to display the integrity check messages directly in the entry editor. This PR accomplishes exactly this.

The location and style of the tooltip is not perfect but as of now these things cannot be changed since they are hardcoded in `controlsfx` (will create a feature request).

column1: This is an atempt to fix the problem with entry editor focus as described in #3052. In detail
column2: when `EntryEditor` opens up
column3: it is not focused automatically. The desired behavior is to focus the first `Textfield` on any of the `EntryEditor`'s tabs.

column1: The way the fix is implemented: when `EntryEditor` is opened
column2: the `JFXPanel` in which is the `TabPane` of the `EntryEditor` is getting the focus
column3: The focus is given implicitly to a focusTraversable node contained in the `JFXPanel`. The selection of the node seems to be ""random"" (even though consistent for a given tree of nodes). As far as I've tested it consistently focuses the first `Textfield` on any tab
column4: which is the desired behavior. I make this pull requested as suggested in #3052 discussion by @Siedlerchr .

column1: I should mention that I ran `gradle check` which results in ""6 tests failed"" in my setup but this was also the result when I ran the test before making any change.

3097lenhard1515701closed2017-08-11T11:09:33Z2017-08-13T19:04:45ZStore changes in source tab when new entry is selectedFixes #3086
The problem was that the source tab only stored changes on focus change and this did not happen when you just select a new entry in the main table.
The PR modifies an attribute in the `EntryEditor` (`movingToDifferentEntry`) and turns it into a `BooleanProperty` so that you can bind to it and react to changes.
EDIT: Also fixes a second (unreported) issue: Now the base panel is marked as dirty when you type something in the source tab.
EDIT 2: Fixes also  #3063
Now the Other fields tab is rebuilt whenever an other field is newly added or removed at the BibEntry. This is achieved with the event system and a new subtype of FieldChangedEvent.

3116lenhard1515701closed2017-08-16T19:31:03Z2017-08-18T15:24:32ZMove event processing from source tab into entry editorSolves the most critical part of #3113
The source tab did not properly unregister itself from the event bus. For some reason
column2: I did not manage to get this working when the source tab takes care of deregistration. Therefore
column3: I moved all event handling out of the source tab and into the entry editor.

column1: Using jvisualvm
column2: I can see that garbage collection works with this PR. Cycling through the main table with the entry editor open increases used RAM. When you force garbage collection
column3: the used heap goes down to close to zero again
column4: instead of staying at a higher plateau. See attached screenshot

column1: ![heap](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1515701/29381572-f60537f6-82c9-11e7-9ad9-20e6208ca648.png)
So this fixes the memory leak. The overall heap size doesn't go down
column2: but that's a different issue.

I added new 'Filter All' and 'Filter None' buttons.  They can be clicked by the user to
check/uncheck all options in the filter menu.  When one of the buttons gets clicked the system will iterate through the existing menu components and toggle the checkmarks and info displayed.
I wasnt sure on the best placement of the buttons in the window so went with the simplest solution

401060220
3123lenhard1515701closed2017-08-18T08:41:11Z2017-08-19T12:51:46Z[WIP] Integrate journal abbreviations into JabRefMeetings are good for easy programming tasks...

This takes care of parts of #919. It takes the existing built-in journal lists and transforms them from text files into source code. We've found the abbreviation loading to be a performance problem. This should reduce this problem a little
column2: because we replace file parsing with class loading and the reading of the lists can be optimized by the compiler. Changes are completely internal to the abbreviation code.

column1: This doesn't check the lists for consistency
column2: the other parts of #919. It just takes the existing lists and turn them into source code.

column1: This doesn't need to be merged into 4.0
column2: but can be included later.

column1: EDIT: Turns out our built-in list has 15195. This is too large for a Java class and I am getting the error `Error:(8
column2: 45) java: code too large` on compilation. So we need to think about this. We can leave the built-in list as a text file (no performance improvement) or distribute it into multiple source code files (seems rather brittle).

3141lenhard1515701closed2017-08-20T14:53:20Z2017-08-25T12:33:22ZIncrease size of file and keywords editorsIn the new EntryEditor
column2: we have the problem that sometimes text in the TextAreas is hard to read
column3: because the areas are very narrow. The reason for this is that Java tries to fit them in the available display space. Examples: #3130 #3117 #2941

column1: This PR sets a minimum size for all TextAreas in the EntryEditor. The value of 70px is rather arbitrary and I'll be happy to get some thoughts if this is good or if more or less is desirable. With this minimum size all TextAreas are nicer to read
column2: even in the cramped up General tab. The only ""problem"" is that you now need to scroll in the General tab most of the time.

column1: All in all I think this should definitly go into 4.0!

3171lenhard1515701closed2017-08-30T13:48:49Z2017-08-31T11:00:42ZAdd undo functionality to the source tabFixes #3170 The problem here
column2: as far as I understand
column3: was that the undo didn't happen on the FXApplication thread.

column1: On top of that
column2: I found the the source tab isn't integrated in the undo framework at all
column3: so I have added this as well. However
column4: it doesn't work problem-free. It seems that the FX CodeArea consumes undo events as well. So when you hit undo in the sourcetab
column5: the CodeArea does the undo and then the UndoManager tries to do it again and fails. It has no consequence
column6: though
column7: apart from an exception

column1: Since this is an improvement (add undo to source tab again)
column2: I would like to merge this even if it's not perfect. I have zero time to dig deeper into these FX problems
column3: and I assume that no one else will do it. So
column4: we can just merge the current state.

3187lenhard1515701closed2017-09-02T13:33:59Z2017-10-18T11:37:02ZAvoid recreation of the EntryEditorThis is one baby step towards fixing the performance and memory issues we are having with the entry editor
Previously
column2: we've created a new EntryEditor instance every time a new entry was selected. This PR avoids that. Instead of recreating a new entry editor
column3: the existing one is reused and just all its contents
column4: i.e. the tabs
column5: are recreated. This doesn't help significantly and we still have the peaks when cycling through the main table with key pressed
column6: but it's a step in the right direction. Here's an overview

column1: ![jabref](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1515701/29995805-2524954c-8ff2-11e7-8e96-76e7e3b030c0.png)
The peaks are from cycling through the main table with down key pressed
column2: but as we can see garbage collection still reduces the used heap massively.

column1: The next step (in a new PR) would be to avoid a recreation of the tabs and to implement a proper lazy initialization of them
column2: so that they only consume memory and processing power when they are actually visible.

column1: I've tested it manually and hope that this doesn't add hidden bugs. After all
column2: the tabs are still created anew so there shouldn't be update problems. Nevertheless
column3: this should receive some manual testing from someone else before it is merged. Lastly
column4: since the tabs are created anew there's now a visible effect when selecting a new entry: The new tabs sort of ""fly in"". I have no problems with that
column5: but if others find that annoying then this PR should not yet be merged before for 4.0 or alternatively only when the tabs are not recreated.

This removes  LatexEditor support (""Push to LatexEditor"") in JabRef.
As stated in #3199 the last update to LatexEditor was made in 2009 (see http://www.latexeditor.org/news.html ) and the software can be considered outdated.
I removed LatexEditor from the applications list in PushToApplications class. I deleted the PushToLatexEditor class since it is now unused.
gradlew check was successful.
I am new here (first pull request) and also still fairly new to Java
column2: so any c&c would be greatly appreciated. Especially let me know if either the practice of commits or this request is not up-to-standard :)

Based on https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/3191#issuecomment-326902439 I added two tests concerning cross referencing.
_What_

column2: where source is cross referencing target.

column1: 2. It reads the database from mentioned example bib file: https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/master/src/test/resources/testbib/crossref.bib and asserts cross reference of two given entries.
_Watchout_
- I was not able to clean code method `assertSourceCrossrefsTarget` further due to the `Optional<>` concept.
- I wrote a small TestDataBuilder `BibEntryBuild.` It is an inner class
column2: because I am uncertain where to put it.

column1: - I wrote an crossref.bib-encapsulating class `DatabaseFromFile` to keep test code readable. It is an inner class
column2: because I did not find a similar wrapper nor did I know where to put it. Its construction uses a path to a file to be parsed to a database.  "1436491

column1: 3218tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-09-13T21:15:38Z2017-09-14T10:31:56ZImprove telemetry"<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: For some reason
column2: some unhandled exceptions are report multiple (meaning in the thousands) times in the Azure telemetry. Thus we regularly hit the daily cap and I get an annoying email. I tried to investigate
column3: but couldn't reproduce the behavior and thus I'm not sure that these changes actually fix the problem. The only difference between logging in the FallbackExceptionHandler to other loggings of errors was the direct usage of `log4j` instead of the usual `LogFactory` approach. Thus I changed it to the later and hope for the best.

column1: While touching the telemetry
column2: I also added logging of the creation of new entries and the created entry type. This information might serve as a guide for a forthcoming improvement of the ""New entry..."" dialog (with sensible defaults and/or completely different approach depending on how users use it).

The offered PR implements functionality discussed in my ""File linking functionality update?"" proposal (http://discourse.jabref.org/t/file-linking-functionality-update/723). It is now possible to use bracketed expressions (like ""[bibtexkey]"" or ""[year]\_[auth]\_[firstpage]"") consistently in:
- BibTex key generator patterns;
- File search regular expressions (for automatic file linking);
- Import file name patterns;
- Import directory patterns.
To maintain consistent formatting
column2: I have created a new BracketedExpressionExpander class which provides its main methods
column3: 'expandBrackets()'. They essentially contain all bracket expansion functionality moved from BibtexKeyPatternUtil
column4: and the BibtexKeyPatternUtil class now extends BracketedExpressionExpander
column5: and uses its static methods. The BracketedExpressionExpander is also used in FileUtil and RegExpBasedFileFinder
column6: avoiding the previous duplication of functionality in BibtexKeyPatternUtil.makeLabel(...) and RegExpBasedFileFinder.getFieldAndFormat(...) methods (both now use BracketedExpressionExpander.expandBrackets() for dealing with *all* aspects of bracket expansion in one place).

column1: The bracketed expressions now can be used for Import File name patterns and Import File Directory patterns
column2: providing consistent behavior of all ""pattern"" tabs in the JabRef ""Preferences"" dialogue; it is also possible to use underscores in the Import File and Directory patterns (e.g. ""[year]\_[auth]\_[pages]"") and to place Import destination directories deeper in the tree (e.g. ""by-author/[authIni1]/[auth]"" Directory Pattern now works as expected
column3: creating ""by-author/P/Pezzotti/2013\_Pezzotti\_211301.pdf"" for the reference: Pezzotti
column4: G. Raman spectroscopy of piezoelectrics Journal of Applied Physics

column1: To retain functionality that was previously implemented by the '\entrytype' Layout pattern
column2: a new bracketed expression ""[entrytype]"" was created and tested. It is suggested that Layout manager is used exclusively for describing layouts in citation lists
column3: and bracketed expressions are used for describing file system and database entry patterns.

column1: The functionality was tested under LinuxMint 18.1 and Ubuntu 16.04. Unfortunately
column2: I could not test it on Windows hosts since I do not have any of them available for Java testing. I have put in provisions to deal with both '/' and '\' directory separators in Directory Patterns
column3: but I would be grateful if someone checks them on a Windows system.

column1: Sincerely

column2: F."". Thus authors specified as ""Last
column3: First"" were not found correctly because of the ""dot"".

3246tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-10-02T13:50:12Z2018-04-26T09:19:40ZImplement native messaging<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: This PR implements `Native Messaging` so that JabRef is able to talk to Firefox and Chrome (or other browser) extensions https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/1284.
I tried around a lot with directly implementing native messaging using Java. It worked in principle but was really unstable (everything JabRef wrote in the command line made crashed Firefox). Thus
column2: in the end
column3: I went for a simple powershell script that handles the ""native messaging"" stuff and converts it to simple command line arguments. As a positive side effect
column4: you can now specify Bibtex code for import directly as a command line argument.

column1: I also took the opportunity to slightly improve the code concerning with the remote listener (the old version didn't allowed arguments with line breaks to be passed).
The installation routine still needs to be automated and this is where I need help. @Siedlerchr @koppor could you please have a look at the following things:
-  Copy [jabref.json](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/nativeMessaging/buildres/jabref.json)
column2: [JabRef.bat](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/JabRef/jabref/nativeMessaging/buildres/JabRef.bat) and [JabRef.ps1](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/nativeMessaging/buildres/JabRef.ps1) to the same directory as `JabRef.exe`.

column1: - Make sure that the correct file name of the JabRef `.jar` file is specified in `JabRef.ps1` under `$jabRefJarFileName`.
- Run `REG ADD ""HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Mozilla\NativeMessagingHosts\org.jabref.jabref"" /ve /d ""C:\path\to\jabref.json"" /f` from the console (with the correct path to the `jabref.json` file).
Things that may be improved in the future:

- [ ] [Breakaway from Firefox process group](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/Add-ons/WebExtensions/Native_messaging#Closing_the_native_app) (otherwise closing Firefox automatically closes JabRef if native messaging was used to open JabRef)

- [ ] Implement things that are special to [Chrome](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/Add-ons/WebExtensions/Native_messaging#Chrome_incompatibilities) and [Edge](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/extensions/guides/native-messaging)

3273michaellass11042539closed2017-10-06T21:23:15Z2017-10-09T00:52:40ZSet WM_CLASS to org-jabref-JabRefMainWM_CLASS is used by certain Un*x window managers
column2: such as GNOME
column3: to map windows

column1: to the corresponding application. Currently WM_CLASS is set to java-lang-Thread
which is very generic and not unique to JabRef. Instead
column2: use reflection to set

column1: it to org-jabref-JabRefMain which resembles the main class name.
The implementation in this PR is based on this blog post:
http://elliotth.blogspot.de/2007/02/fixing-wmclass-for-your-java.html
By now you find similar solutions in several Java applications. I'm not aware of a more convenient way to manually set WM_CLASS.

I tested the change on a Linux system running GNOME 3 and also on macOS to rule out any cross-platform issues. Also I chose the WM_CLASS name that matches the StartupWMClass in [buildres/snapcraft/jabref.desktop](../blob/master/buildres/snapcraft/jabref.desktop)
column2: so no changes are necessary in there.

3305halirutan511683closed2017-10-15T00:50:20Z2017-10-16T09:15:47ZImprovement for Java FX font rendering on Linux"The font-rendering of Java FX on Linux seems to be generally not as good as on other systems. I found the repo [Java FX hates Linux](https://github.com/woky/javafx-hates-linux) helpful which made a comparison for different settings for the *prism rendering engine*.
That being said
column2: I found simply setting

column1: ``` java
System.setProperty(""prism.text""
System.setProperty(""prism.lcdtext""
column2: ""true"");

column1: provides the best font rendering without having to make changes in css that might affect other systems.
This pull-request adds a checkbox under Settings -> Appearance -> Look and Feel to turn this on after a restart. I incorporated it into the preference framework. On Linux
column2: it is turned on in the default settings.

column1: ![settings](http://i.imgur.com/yHvh8AN.png)
When turning it is turned on
column2: the fonts are less blurry and the color bleaching is highly reduced (although we don't use gray scale font smoothing!). Compare these two screenshots:

column1: 1. [Tweaks turned off](http://i.imgur.com/BsFhpmk.png)
2. [Tweaks turned on](http://i.imgur.com/Ld8UJm2.png)

column1: This PR aims to fix #3292 by removing the refresh button completely and monitoring the pdf files automatically for changes. In the progress of the implementation a few refactorings were made:
- Extract the file monitoring functionality from `FileUpdateMonitor` to a new class and convert the timestamp-based method to the new nio watcher interface.
- Extract the conflict handling code by external bib file changes from the base panel to a new class `DatabaseChangeMonitor`
column2: where also some of the old code from `FileUpdateMonitor` now finds a new home. This class is still a bit ugly but in my opinion better than before. I hope that the conflict handling still works as expected. I tested it but might have missed some special cases/configurations.
