3327halirutan511683closed2017-10-20T06:09:44Z2017-10-20T17:52:37ZFix location bundle with fast accessThis PR addresses the issue I mentioned under [Localization memory](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/3187#issuecomment-337464813). To provide a reasonable implementation and not only a bugfix I had to change the layout. These things bothered me the most:
- `LocalizationBundle` and `Localization` were calling each other. We needed `Localization` to create the keys in the bundle and on the other hand
column2: the `LocalizationBundle` was only used in the `Localization` class

column1: - `Localization` seemed like a quick fix to provide messages as bundle to Java FX
- On each call to any function in these classes
column2: the unescaping of messages was done again. This
column3: in particular
column4: was the reason why showed up as hot spot in the profiler

column1: To unify the implementation
column2: I based the complete `Localization` framework on two instances (menus and messages) of `LocalizationBundle` and made this an internal class as it should not be used without it. The bundles are (re)created when `setLanguage` is called and contain the unescaped keys and messages for the specified language as a fast hash table.

column1: This enables two things: (1) We can pass the `LocalizationBundle` instance directly to Java FX with `getMessages` and since we only pass the reference to the hash table
column2: it will be instantaneous. (2) Every call to `lang` or `menuTitle` is a simple lookup in the hash table and a replacement of possible parameters in the string.

column1: The public API for `Localization`
column2: meaning `lang`
column3: `menuTitle`
column4: `getMessages` and `setLanguage` did not change and works as expected. During profiling/debugging I noticed
column5: however
column6: that there is a flaw in the JabRef startup. The language is set after the initialization of the preferences. At least one preference setting uses a localized string in a static field. Since when uninitialized
column7: the `Localization` reverts back to ""en""
column8: these strings will never be in the user language (see [this issue](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3326)). Furthermore
column10: the `Localization` framework will always be initialized several times. Once in the init of the preferences and once further down in `main`.

column1: This can only be fixed by pushing `setLanguage` to the initialization of the preferences which I did. One additional minor thing was that one message key was used escaped and had to be unescaped. Other than that
column2: this implementation worked out of the box and passed all existing localization tests.

column1: I commented my code heavily and would be glad if someone would review it. Don't forget that I'm looking only about 5 days on the code base and it is very likely I have overlooked something."3101638556

3331halirutan511683closed2017-10-21T05:13:54Z2017-10-21T20:30:44ZInitializing EntryEditor Tabs on focusThis is a very small fix with big implications for performance and memory. The reasoning is simple: Currently
column2: all editor tabs (extending from `FieldsEditorTab`) are initialized when a new entry is selected. So even if the user is only browsing through the entry table with the editor open
column3: on each new BibEntry we create all the tabs for each entry from scratch. This can in the case of `FieldsEditorTab` simply prevented by moving this initialization to `initialize` which is called when the tab gets focus. This PR addresses this issue.

column1: I want to give a detailed analysis because there is much more potential when we slightly rework how the `EntryEditor` and its tabs work. First of all
column2: this is the memory increase when I scroll the 209 entry example `jabref-authors.bib` with the current master branch.

column1: ![img](http://i.imgur.com/tt99OZf.png)
In the middle I start after running the GC with about 140MB and after scrolling the list
column2: I ended up with 1.9GB. 99% of this comes directly from the `EntryEditor`. After the patch I propose
column3: the memory situation is vastly improved

column1: ![img](http://i.imgur.com/AhRSD0E.png)
We need less than 400MB at the peaks and the GC seems to be able to do a much better job. It's not only an improvement in memory
column2: but the performance increases dramatically.

column1: ## Where to go from here?
These things should be fixed in a next step:
1. `org.jabref.gui.entryeditor.EntryEditor#addTabs` is the major hotspot now because it recreates all tabs on a new entry.
2. ensure that all tabs get this late initialization on focus.
3. tabs should not be recreated at all
column2: they should be kept as objects in `EntryEditor` and only get notified when a new entry is selected.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: I don't see that I can do this on my own without breaking some of the various information flows on updates in the tabs (esp. the source tab). But if someone started to work on this I would join. These are the things I would change first:

column1: 1. almost all tabs get `frame
column2: panel
column3: entryType
column4: this
column5: entry` on construction. This needs to go away. `EntryEditor` is an instance of `EntryContainer` and tabs can get the current entry. We need similar things for the other parameters. In essences
column6: it should be `new EntryEditorTab(entryEditorInstance)`.

column1: 2. On `initialize` the tab should check if it is initialized and if the entry has changed
3. The entryEditor has a list of *all* tabs that are created on construction and it only notifies them on entry change.
### The ""sliding tab problem""
Especially with this faster version
column2: the problem of the tabs sliding in from the left on recreation becomes more visible. I have no simple solution to this especially since I'm not sure how many tabs there theoretically can be. It's these line in `addTabs`

column1: // General fields from preferences
EntryEditorTabList tabList = Globals.prefs.getEntryEditorTabList();
for (int i = 0; i < tabList.getTabCount(); i++) {
FieldsEditorTab newFieldsEditorTab = new FieldsEditorTab(frame
column2: panel
column3: tabList.getTabFields(i)
column4: this
column5: false

column1: false
column2: entry);

column1: newFieldsEditorTab.setText(tabList.getTabName(i));
tabs.add(newFieldsEditorTab);
If we have a reasonable number of tabs
column2: the best and clearest solution would be to just disable the ones that should not be shown. This will give a fixed EntryEditor layout that works nice
column3: but I'm not sure it would piss user of if they have to endure disabled tabs.

column1: The second solution would be to maintain a list of all tabs and one with the currently visible tabs (`tabbed.getTabs()`). This will again lead to a wiggling tabs header
column2: but not as bad as before. On entry change
column3: we just modify `tabbed` to display correct tabs.

column1: The third solution would be to simply close tabs programmatically but that interferes with the current `TabClosingPolicy.UNAVAILABLE`"407422

3340halirutan511683closed2017-10-24T05:46:10Z2017-10-25T09:40:34ZUsed late initialization for context menusI believe I could bring down the performance impact of the context menus to a bare minimum. I reported this in https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3335 and @tobiasdiez provided me with the hint how this could work. Against his suggestion to not overshoot
column2: I decided to prove my point that even those small context menus have a significant impact because things will sum up in the end and those menus are newly instantiated for every visible field in the editor.

column1: The starting point was the current master-branch and profiling it by going through only 50 bib-entries. This means that the context menus are instantiated for the visible text fields. This has an impact on performance and memory and
column2: unfortunately
column3: it is not only a tiny fraction.

column1: ## Memory
Notable are the columns ""Objects""
column2: which are all objects that are created by this method and underlying sub calls and the overall ""Size"".

column1: ![mem1](http://i.imgur.com/pjBJSlF.png)
With almost 40% of the overall memory size
column2: it's definitely something to look into.

column1: ## Performance
The performance is with 8% not so large but still noticeable.
![perf1](http://i.imgur.com/STSGgNj.png)
## Fixing it
By using the `Supplier` interface
column2: we can move the instantiation to the point where the user actually right-clicks into the field. I debugged this
column3: and it seems to work nice. The outcome was as expected. Since no one actually triggers the context menu by just browsing through the list
column4: it vanished altogether. Here is the used memory with this PR created by exactly scrolling through the 50 entries. First the memory footprint

column1: ![mem2](http://i.imgur.com/dRrKaxs.png)
and here the performance impact
![perf2](http://i.imgur.com/HgJNhLl.png)
In conclusion
column2: this means as long as the user doesn't need a context menu
column3: we have no memory or performance impact at all.

column1: ## Note
I updated the `checkstyle` version in the Gradle built. I like to write comments
column2: and now it doesn't prevent me any longer from using `{@link ...}` in doc-comments to classes that are otherwise not used.

3353tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-10-26T00:57:55Z2017-10-28T03:51:08ZRefactor collab package"<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: This PR refactors the collab package and splits it into gui and logic parts. More precisely
column2: the code that was used to determine the differences between two databases now resides in logic
column3: while the rest went to the gui package (one might try to extract even more code to logic but this is a first good start in my opinion).

column1: I tried to not change the functionality. This of course means that I tried not to introduce bugs (although I'm sure there will be small glitches) but it also implies that I didn't improved the code too much. If somebody has time
column2: he or she is really invited to have a look at the feature. Many things are not yet implemented (e.g. a real metadata difference) and the ui is just ugly.

column1: However
column2: there is one thing which did changed: previously it was a kind of 3-way merge between the last saved version
column3: the current state and the external changes to the bib file. However
column4: the current state was taken into account only sometimes (and sometimes in the wrong way). Thus I removed this part completely and moved to a 2-way merge between the last saved version and the external changes. In rare cases
column5: this might lead to an unnecessary notification of external changes (namely exactly when the external changes coincide with what the user changed since the last save).

column1: If you merge
column2: it probably preferable to not smash the commits.

column1: This should fix (most) IndexOutOfBounds exceptions in the entry editor. The problem is that the source code editor cannot handle updates when it is hidden. (In particular
column2: there is no problem with the bindings etc....it is just a bug in the library we use; for normal text fields there is absolutely no problem in having an active binding while the control is hidden). In order to circumvent this problem
column3: the source tab now removes the code editor as soon as it looses focus.

column2: why

column1: So here is now a real fix of these problems in the source editor (index out of bounds
column2: paste
column3: select all
column4: update
column5: ...). The problem was that updates to the editor were not performed on the javafx thread although they were wraped in a `runInJavaFXThread` call. The reason was that this method would actually submit tasks to the executor
column6: which would then start a new thread. So the fix only happens in `DefaultTaskExecutor`
column7: the rest of the changes are minor cosmetic improvements to get rid of globals or base panels in the source tab.

column1: This PR adds a simple GUI test for the source editor
column2: which I used to track down the index of out bounds exception. It uses [TestFX](https://github.com/TestFX/TestFX)
column3: which seems to be a good framework for javafx gui tests. For example
column4: it is possible to run the unit tests in a headless method - thus allowing it to run on travis. For me
column5: the biggest advantage is that you can isolate different parts of the system (i.e. only add the source tab) and ignore the rest of the application. Thus you can write ""unit tests for ui"".

column1: Disclaimer: I will not invest any more work in these gui tests. But since some of you were quite in favor of having a gui test suite
column2: I thought I share with you what I have so far.

3418halirutan511683closed2017-11-09T04:54:55Z2017-11-11T00:39:26ZChecking Java version on startupThis is not quite ready for review
column2: but I appreciate some feedback. Since `localizationUpdate` seems broken
column3: the messages are currently not added and I'm waiting for the fix.The logic behind the java check is as follows:

column1: 1. In `gradle.build` we can define the `minRequiredJavaVersion` which is added as a value to `build.properties` as this was the most fitting place and it makes the version check quite flexible. I did not use an upper bound for the version but a boolean `allowJava9` indicator. The reasoning behind it is that a developer who is actually working on the Java 9 support just has to change this value to make JabRef start.
2. I put the version check as a method into `BuildInfo`. Other possible places would be `Globals` or when we give the build-info as a parameter then `JavaVersionCheck` itself. Suggestions?
3. The version check is called pretty early in `main` (as soon as localization is set up). I didn't bother to put the single error dialog into a separate class. Therefore
column2: the logic of checking
column3: showing the message and probably exiting is done directly there. Is this acceptable?

column1: The version check itself has the only requirement to successfully access `System.getProperty(""java.version"")`. I implemented a very *optimistic* check that doesn't fail if we cannot determine or compare the versions. Only if we are sure that the used version is not sufficient
column2: it will fail.

column1: Since quite some time passed since the last issue was created concerning the entry editor
column2: I feel like this component is getting way to stable and no longer annoys users. Thinking hard about how to reintroduce the necessary amount of bugs
column3: I hereby propose to rework the entry editor toolbar using JavaFX.

column1: Before:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5037600/33519852-e35fbd2a-d7af-11e7-8982-93530fc0599a.png)
After:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5037600/33519858-072366f8-d7b0-11e7-8a87-1ed5a63b7f23.png)
I tried to clean-up the ui as much as possible by removing a few buttons and changing the size/space.
The following buttons were removed:
- all buttons that do not have a global effect on the whole entry but are concerned with a specific field
- ""generate bibtex key"" moved to the key field in the entry editor
- ""find linked files"" removed completely (it was not working anyway
column2: and nobody complained)

column1: - ""write metadata to pdf"" moved to file field
- ""help"": removed completely (since otherwise there was not enough space to have a nice display of the type label)
Other changes:
- left click on type label shows ""change type menu""
- the entry editor contained some (unused) code that checked the bibtex key for duplication and validity. I extracted the code and turned it into new integrity checkers.

column2: this is a fix for the issue #2810.

column1: We added a new listener that automatically updates the timestamp of changed entries if the feature is enabled in the options (""Update timestamp on modification""). The listener was added to the BasePanel class so that it could listen on the whole database to also work with changes created by other sources (like cleanup operations).
The listener is ""public static"" so that it can be accessed by the added test cases.
- [x] Change in CHANGELOG.md described
- [x] Tests created for changes
- [x] Manually tested changed features in running JabRef
### Problem with dependency on JabRefPreferences

The test cases added with UpdateTimestampListenerTest cause the test [TestArchitectureTests#testsAreIndependent()](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/master/src/test/java/org/jabref/architecture/TestArchitectureTests.java#L54) to fail as the new tests are dependent on JabRefPreferences.
We were initially using Globals.prefs directly. To remove the dependency on Globals
column2: we changed it so that a JabRefPreferences object is passed to the constructor of the listener instead. This means that the tests are only dependent on JabRefPreferences now.

column1: But we don't know how to avoid this dependency. We tried to pass the TimeStampPreferences object directly to the constructor of the listener (which would remove the dependency). This is
column2: however
column3: not feasible as the TimeStampsPreferences object returned by Globals.prefs.getTimeStampPreferences() does not reflect any changes made in the options menu. This would mean that changes to the option ""Update timestamp on modification"" (or the date format) would only apply after a restart of JabRef.

column1: We had a look online on how to test with preferences but according to the [JabRef testing how-tos](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/wiki/Code-Howtos#preferences-in-tests)
column2: creating a mock object of JabRefPreferences and mocking the needed method calls should be a valid approach.

column1: ### Potentially unwanted behavior
As the timestamp is set on any change to the entry
column2: if the user decides to change the timestamp by hand it will be reset immediately. We are not sure if this behavior is wanted or not.

3443jupf4948016closed2017-11-18T12:32:16Z2017-11-27T17:58:18ZFix for issue #3381Because the javafx Tooltip used in the [GlobalSearchBar](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/master/src/main/java/org/jabref/gui/search/GlobalSearchBar.java) cannot render HTML
column2: @tobiasdiez recommended in #3381  to create a TextFlow object in the [SearchDescriber](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/master/src/main/java/org/jabref/logic/search/rules/describer/SearchDescriber.java) classes for structuring the Text.

column1: I made the changes to return a TextFlow and its working fine so far without changing the logic that is used to build the text.  I moved the search.rules.describer package like proposed from the logic package to the gui package. The existing tests were moved accordingly but still needs to be rewritten for the new TextFlow results.
There are some open questions i would like to ask:
1. With no Styling of the Tooltip
column2: the readability was really bad (black text on grey background)
column3: so I changed the styling to look like the other Tooltips in the bar. Hope it was okay to do this in the context of this issue? I created a new styleclass for this in the Main.css to not change any other styled elements.

column1: 2. the [SearchQuery](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/master/src/main/java/org/jabref/logic/search/SearchQuery.java) class stores a description of the search. It is created with the SearchDescribers. But they are now inside the gui package and return a TextFlow. So there is a javafx dependency in the SearchQuery class which resides in the logic package at the moment. This doesnt sound right to me? Should the class be moved to the gui package too?

3. The [GroupDialog](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/master/src/main/java/org/jabref/gui/groups/GroupDialog.java) class uses a SearchQuery object to get a search description. This class is written with Swing and is not compatible to the now returned TextFlow. If I understand it right
column2: the project is migrating to use javaFX. So I want to propose that I write a compatibility method in the GroupDialog class to create an HTML string from the given TextFlow to be compatible while the GroupDialog is still using Swing.

column1: 4. Sadly the localized strings used in the SearchDescribers included the HTML tag elements.. So in many cases it is not possible to use existing translations.. just because the tags are gone. I'm not sure what to do about this. It could be possible to remove the tags manually from the translations. Not sure how long this would take..
That's how the tooltip looks with the changes:
![screenshot-2017-11-18--13 15 28](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4948016/32980197-9c017e62-cc62-11e7-86a6-b5c0c0010ac8.png)
There seems to be something wrong with the logic of the tooltip text creation
column2: the first few words repeat itself. And it already happened prior to my changes (see the image in #3381) But I didnt had time to look very closely into this. Should I open a new issue for this problem?

column1: I hope I didn't forget anything. I'm happy to hear your feedback!

column2: why

column1: This PR implements #1664 by adding a group that contains all entries referenced in a given aux-file. So far the code is only a prototype
column2: but it already works really well. What is missing is that changes in the aux file are automatically recognized and handled (this should be easy to accomplish). The user interface is very very basic and only contains a text field where the user can specify the path to the aux file (in light of the upcoming rewrite of the groups dialog in javafx #2643
column3: I don't want to spent to much time at ui stuff).

column1: I have two questions:
- ~~The implementation so far is against our architecture. The new group (`TexGroup`) is in the model but uses the `AuxParser` from the logic. Any ideas how to resolve this issue? More and more
column2: I don't like the strict rule that model is not allowed to access logic - how I'm supposed to create ""intelligent"" objects in the model if they are not allowed to use advanced stuff from the logic package?~~

column1: - The file path right now is stored as an absolute path. Is this ok? If not
column2: what should be the ""base"" of a relative path? The bib file?

3454lenhard1515701closed2017-11-24T10:56:09Z2017-11-24T11:27:02ZReplace swingx with standard swingIn order to be able to properly move to Java 9 (see #2594)
column2: we need to get rid of all accesses of internal APIs. Unfortunately
column3: we also use libraries that make such internal accesses and we need to find a solution for that.

column1: One of these libraries is swingx. Originally by Sun
column2: it is no longer maintained since quite a while we could not even upgrade to the newest version
column3: because of bugs in the library. It is time to get rid of this dependency. This PR replaces the usage of swingx with regular Swing components. Only the new entries dialog and the side pane are affected. For the new entries dialog
column4: the change is trivial (just using a regular layout manager). For the side pane
column5: a few changes are needed
column6: but I can make it roughly resemble the old layout.

column1: There's one bigger change
column2: though
column3: that I happen to like very much: The side panes are no longer exclusive
column4: you can display them together. That means that I can have the web search and the groups panel open at the same time. Personally
column5: I think that's pretty cool and I would like to keep it that way. You can of course still disable the side panes independent of each other. Here's a screenshot:

column1: ![sidepane](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1515701/33206932-2e6bd6fa-d10c-11e7-96b2-58f28f0f3bee.png)

3458lenhard1515701closed2017-11-25T15:39:46Z2018-01-02T12:47:21ZRemove dependency to jgoodies-looksJgoodies-looks uses internal APIs (see https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/2594#issuecomment-346829982 )
column2: which means that it causes problems with Java 9. This PR removes this dependency. The biggest change is that two Look and Feels go and that particularily affects Linux users.

column1: I have used the Nimbus Look and Feel as the new default for Linux
column2: but we can change that or even search for better Java 9-compatible Look and Feels. I have also added a preferences migration in case a user has set one of the incompatible Look and Feels.

column1: I would suggest that we wait with merging this after we have release 4.1. Java 9 does not yet matter for 4.1 and we should give the Linux users a stable JabRef that still has the old Look and Feels before moving on.

3459muntrob33424784closed2017-11-26T16:52:23Z2018-02-06T17:31:20Z[WIP] Fix for issue 3109In the comments to issue #3109 I already presented my solution approaches for the FileAnnotationTab's design change. This discussion should be continued here.
There were two situations I have presented a design approach:
1. The linked file has no annotations
2. The linked file has annotations
If there are annotations in the linked file
column2: two design solution approaches have been discussed: Either realising it with a list or a table. No matter which of these solutions is chosen
column3: it would be nice to be able to order the annotations by Date
column4: Author or Page.

column1: - So a table might be the clearest solution.
- Sorting a list on the other hand side could be realised by implementing a DropDown Menu were the user can select what the list should be sorted by.
I implemented the ""No Annotations"" approach
column2: so that the right side of the FileAnnotationTab showing the annotation's attributes is either disabled (if there are ""no annotations"" in the linked file) or enabled (if there are annotations)."10315458196

column1: 3460tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-11-27T19:49:15Z2017-12-08T09:35:14ZOnly build master branch on push"Our current workflow is to create a branch on the main JabRef fork and then open a PR for it. This
column2: however
column3: leads to two travis builds: one for the new push to JabRef and one for the PR.

column1: There seems to be no elegant way to force travis to
- always build PRs
- but don't build PRs from main branches twice
See https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/6612. I followed [the suggested solution on stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/a/31882307/873661) and only white-listed the master branch.
Thus pushes to master still trigger a build
column2: as well as all PRs. However
column3: pushes to other branches on main does not result in build. Thus only one build is executed if you open a PR from a main branch. Disadvantage: you have to open a PR to get a build from a different branch. I don't think this is a huge disadvantage since it is exactly our current workflow.

3470koppor1366654closed2017-11-29T12:43:15Z2017-11-30T17:08:34ZDiscussion: Use crowdin for translation.In comparison to transifex
column2: we have the automatic GitHub integration.

column1: ## Pros and cons of crowdin
- `+`: Easy translation interface. Users can start joining at https://crwd.in/jabref.

- `+`: Nice status overview - see https://crowdin.com/project/jabref - internal link: https://crowdin.com/project/jabref/settings#translations - fixes fixes https://github.com/JabRef/help.jabref.org/issues/171
- `+` Translators do not require a login at GitHub and do not need to work with pull requests etc.
- `+` Translations can still be made using our GitHub workflow
- Exclamation marks are escaped. However
column2: this is no issue
column3: because we unescape them: https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/d45d7ca381c31fab2e41e0693948b11e5068887b/src/main/java/org/jabref/logic/l10n/LocalizationKey.java#L25

column1: - `-` At least one review of the translated string is required

- `-` We cannot create [our translation status page](https://github.com/JabRef/help.jabref.org/blob/gh-pages/en/TranslatingGUI.md#localization-files-status-2017-11-29-1957---branch-master-42ba568ea) anymore (using `syncLang.py`) as crowdin either (i)  does not put a key at all or (ii) puts the English translation in the properties file. Checking for equality does not help as `OK` is translated to `OK`.
- `-` It seems that generating the pull request has to be triggered manually.
I would vote to go for crowdin to make it easy for interested people to work on the translation.
## TODOs
- [ ] Check why our language file checker fails and adapt it accordingly

- [x] `id` vs `in`. Result: The ISO-Code for Indonesia changed from ""in"" to ""id"". Java uses only the old one. See https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/Locale.html#Locale(java.lang.String)
column2: but Crowdin uses the new one. With a new mapping configuration on Crowdin

column1: 3473derTimme9265790closed2017-11-30T12:31:02Z2017-12-13T14:41:31ZFetcher for IACR eprints"I'm working on a new fetcher for [IACR eprints](https://eprint.iacr.org/)
column2: as I need a lot of these for my current work.

column1: IACR does not provide a real API
column2: so the information needs to be parsed out of their (really simple) HTML.

column1: @devs: Are there any special requirements for fetchers? (I couldn't find any
column2: but the whole HTML parsing thing might be a problem concerning maintainability - on the other hand
column3: I use IACR for quite a while now and the web interface hasn't changed (visibly at least)).

column1: The idea is to have the following features:
- [x] Fetch based on ID (like `2017/1556`)
- [x] Fetched entry is of type `misc` and contains:
- [x] Title
- [x] Authors
- [x] Url (contains the version)
- [x] Note with `\url{https://eprint.iacr.org/<identifier>}` (recommended by IACR)
- [x] Howpublished like `Cryptology ePrint Archive
column2: Report <identifier>` (recommended by IACR)

column1: - [x] Version (most recent)
- [x] Date (of the most recent version)
- [x] Abstract
- [x] The encoding fits the library encoding (see b76a3f742f593e775a93997d67c94b2d954fc485
The following could also make sense:
- Get fulltext (if that means to download the pdf - I haven't used this feature with other fetchers yet
column2: so I don't really know what exactly it does)

column1: - Get the ""also published in"" information (see e.g. [this paper](https://eprint.iacr.org/2017/1118)) and DOI
column2: if present (e.g. [this paper](https://eprint.iacr.org/2016/119))

column1: - Get keywords

- Search in IACR preprints (e.g. for title) - but I suspect this would require us to download the complete archive or somehow ""fill out"" their search form (by crafting the corresponding POST request) programatically

3509tobiasdiez5037600closed2017-12-10T14:46:36Z2017-12-23T14:06:10ZFixes #3472: Files starting with BibTeX key of a similar entry are no longer found by mistake<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: Fixes #3472.

The auto-link algorithm just checked if the file starts with the BibTeX key. This leads to a lot of false positives since ""Einstein1902a.pdf"" is found for the entry ""Einstein1902"" although this pdf probably belongs to a second paper by Einstein that was published in the same year.
This is fixed in this PR.

With the proposed implementation also the pdf file ""Einstein1902aboutSomething.pdf"" is no longer found (since there is really no possibility in telling the difference to ""Einstein1902a - a second paper.pdf""). Thus the user is advised to add some non-letter character after the key.

3523lenhard1515701closed2017-12-12T15:34:22Z2018-01-02T18:38:02ZRefactor shared package into the architectureThe new Java 9 module system brings us the possibility to actually modularize inside Java
column2: i.e. to distribute our source code into multiple modules and specify dependencies and constraints among them
column3: much in the way that we do it now with tests. But to extract modules
column4: there can be no cyclic dependencies among them.

column1: The `model` package is our best candidate for extracting a new module. Here the last dependency that coupled it to transitively to everything else was the `shared` package. This PR refactors the shared package and puts most of it into `logic`. I broke the dependency from `model` by introducing a number of interface that the `logic` layer implements. These interfaces will have just one implementation now
column2: but at least they break the dependency cycle.

column1: This is just a refactoring
column2: so I think it should be merged after the release of 4.1

3530koppor1366654closed2017-12-14T15:17:23Z2017-12-20T08:59:05ZDescribe new workflow with Crowdin[Crowdin](http://translate.jabref.org/) automatically adds missing translations to the other languages.
With our `localizationUpdate` task
column2: we also do that. This leads to conflicts at the Crowdin synchronizations.

column1: This PR proposes to
1. update the description of how to add new strings
2. update the tests to enable the translations being a subset of the existing translations.
After each sync
column2: the translation will reappear. So we have a short time window where the translations are missing and that translators using GitHub do not see these new translations. I would accept that.

3553halirutan511683closed2017-12-20T05:13:24Z2018-01-03T19:13:15ZFix group search performanceThis includes currently 2 changes:
Fixes #2852
1. The input field for the group search is delayed now. It waits until the user has finished typing and starts the search afterward. This increases the usability and prevents lags during typing.

2. The RecursiveTreeElement caches the current predicate so that branches of the group tree are not tested over and over again. This is an ugly solution so far but we need to test if this or something similar (but beautiful) boosts the performance considerably.

3601schneems59744closed2018-01-04T03:27:28Z2018-01-04T19:36:44ZGet more Open Source Helpers[CodeTriage](https://www.codetriage.com/) is an app I have maintained
for the past 4-5 years with the goal of getting people involved in
Open Source projects like this one. The app sends subscribers a random
open issue for them to help ""triage"". For some languages you can also
suggested areas to add documentation.
The initial approach was inspired by seeing the work of the small
core team spending countless hours asking ""what version was
this in"" and ""can you give us an example app"". The idea is to
outsource these small interactions to a huge team of volunteers
and let the core team focus on their work.
I want to add a badge to the README of this project. The idea is to
provide an easy link for people to get started contributing to this
project. A badge indicates the number of people currently subscribed
to help the repo. The color is based off of open issues in the project.
Here are some examples of other projects that have a badge in their
README:
- https://github.com/crystal-lang/crystal
- https://github.com/rails/rails
- https://github.com/codetriage/codetriage
Thanks for building open source software
column2: I would love to help you find some helpers."101011

3621tobiasdiez5037600closed2018-01-09T12:42:49Z2018-06-03T22:06:39Z[WIP] Main table JavaFX migrationThis PR tracks the progress of the migration of the maintable to JavaFX. See also the [Maintable in JavaFX project](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/projects/4). The current version can be downloaded [here](https://builds.jabref.org/maintable-beta/).
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5037600/35536179-65fd66f6-0546-11e8-8a45-9c079514da46.png)
Please report any bugs that appear or missing features
column2: which are not listed below. Moreover
column3: we appreciate feedback about the general design (what do guys like
column4: what not)

column1: Known bugs:
- [ ] Some input controls (like check boxes) look odd
- [ ] Smaller things outlined [here](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/3621#issuecomment-369646377) and [here](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/3621#issuecomment-378598558)
- [ ] Drag & drop to and from the table does not work #3765
- [ ] Ranking is not shown (and thus not editable)

- [ ] Float mode does not work (partly because of [unresolved feature request for Java](https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8091326))  [code to fix](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37768326/group-by-function-in-javafx-table)
- [ ] Linux / Mac OS: Resizing the columns per drag & drop does not work nicely (https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/3621#issuecomment-368821666)
- [ ] Linux: Column separator are not shown on hover (https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/3621#issuecomment-368821666)
- [ ] Performance of search is poor for large databases https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/1513#issuecomment-361528430

- [x] <s>Magnifier icon is not colored correctly - we accept that workaround until we implement something really cool as proposed at https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3535</s> Follow up at https://github.com/koppor/jabref/issues/341
- [x] <s>Mouse wheel for tabs in entry editor works in the wrong way - up/down reversed in comparison to Firefox (by @koppor)</s> Follow up at https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/4089
- [x] <s>When in the maintable
column2: <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>F</kbd> does not focus the search field  (by @koppor)</s> Follow up at https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3062

column1: - [x] Import does not work
column2: see https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/3621#issuecomment-387529415

column1: - [x] Trailing thread even after JabRef is closed https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/3621#issuecomment-372785852

- [x] The colors have to harmonized and sometimes the text is hard to read (black on dark background e.g. in the search or for active rows). Reported in https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3678#issuecomment-367321389.
- [x] Deleting of entries does not work
column2: leads to exception

column1: - [x] When columns are reorded by drag & drop
column2: then the new order is not saved (i.e. lost after closing JabRef)

column1: - [x] Reordering of tabs using drag'n'drop is not possible any more (by @koppor): [code to fix](https://github.com/sibvisions/javafx.DndTabPane) or wait until [Java 10](https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8187074)
- [x] Columns cannot be resized even if there is an <-> arrow indicated that it would be possible (by @koppor)
- [x] The size of the entry editor sometimes resets leading to a very small editor
- [x] The columns are slightly sized too large if a vertical scrollbar is visible
- [x] The icons in the right toolbar of the entry editor are sized to small
- [x] Saving a file leads to an IllegalStateException
- [x] The searchbar sometimes steals the focus from the maintable.
- [x] JabRef might no longer start on MacOS https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3267#issuecomment-361511845
- [x] JabRef might freeze on Linux https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3373#issuecomment-361757196
- [x] CTRL + TAB does only sometimes work. The toolbar steals the focus. Might be fixed by #3684
- [x] Changes to entries don't mark database as changed.
- [x] File annotation tab is not shown and throws exception https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/3621#issuecomment-361647223
- [x] Paste of new entries does not work
- [x] It is no longer possible to select multiple entries by holding mouse button: [code to fix](https://community.oracle.com/thread/2621389)
Changelog:
Fixed:
- Italic text is now rendered correctly. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3356

- The entry editor no longer gets corrupted after using the source tab. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3532 https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3608 https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3616
- We fixed multiple issues where entries did not show up after import if a search was active. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/1513 https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3219
- We fixed an issue where the group tree was not updated correctly after an entry was changed. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3618
- We fixed an issue where a right-click in the main table selected a wrong entry. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3267
- We fixed an issue where in rare cases entries where overlayed in the main table. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3281
- We fixed an issue where selecting a group messed up the focus of the main table / entry editor. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3367
- We fixed an issue where composite author names were sorted incorrectly. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/2828
- We fixed an issue where the custom file column were sorted incorrectly. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3119
- We fixed an issues where the entry losses focus when a field is edited and at the same time used for sorting. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3373
- We fixed an issue where the menu on Mac OS was not displayed in the usual Mac-specific way. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3146
- We fixed an issue where the groups tree of the last database was still shown even after the database was already closed.
- We fixed an issue where the ""Open file dialog"" may disappear behind other windows. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3410
- We fixed an issue where the default icon of a group was not colored correctly.
- We reworked the ""Edit file"" dialog to make it resizeable and improved the workflow for adding and editing files https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/2970
- We fixed an issue where the month was not shown in the preview https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3239.
Changed:
- The special fields like `Printed` and `Read status` now show gray icons when the row is hovered.
- We added a button in the tab header which allows you to close the database with one click. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/494
- Sorting in the main table now takes information from cross-referenced entries into account. https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/2808
- If a group has a color specified
column2: then entries matched by this group have a small colored bar in front of them in the main table.

column1: - Change default icon for groups to a circle because a colored version of the old icon was hard to distinguish from its black counterpart.
- In the main table
column2: the context menu appears now when you press the ""context menu"" button on the keyboard. [feature request in the forum](http://discourse.jabref.org/t/how-to-enable-keyboard-context-key-windows)

column1: - We added icons to the group side panel to quickly switch between `union` and `intersection` group view mode https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3269
Removed:
- The feature to ""mark entries"" was removed and merged with the groups functionality.  For migration
column2: a group is created for every value of the `__markedentry` field and the entry is added to this group.

column1: - The number column was removed.
- We removed the coloring of cells in the maintable according to whether the field is optional/required.
- We removed a few commands from the right-click menu that are not needed often and thus don't need to be placed that prominently:
- Print entry preview: available through entry preview
- All commands related to marking: marking is not yet reimplemented
- Set/clear/append/rename fields: available through Edit menu
- Manage keywords: available through Edit menu
- Copy linked files to folder:  available through File menu
Migrated features:
- [x] Sorting (Shift + click for multi-column sort)
- [x] Filtering by search and groups
- [x] Context menu (with linked files) for the file icon
- [x] Right-click menu
- [x] Setting special fields like reading status / priority / ... through the main table

I would like to ask all contributors with write-access to complete the lists above (with links to a comment with further details if necessary) with new bugs or missing features as they are discovered."49111342918248294491

3630koppor1366654closed2018-01-12T15:09:38Z2018-01-12T15:56:23ZAdd gitter badgeThis addresses https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3586
In the DevCall
column2: we decided
column3: that we will try to use Gitter and see how it goes.

column1: The main arguments were:
- easy to join for new users

- offer help for new developers since the burden of initial JabRef development is high for newcomers - even if we have https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/wiki/High-Level-Documentation and https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/wiki/Code-Howtos
- Nearly none of the developers uses Slack
- does not clutter the Skype chat of the developers
- developers can use [pinned tabs](https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/pinned-tabs-keep-favorite-websites-open) to keep gitter always opened
We will shutdown gitter in case there won't be much support from @JabRef/developers there (because lack of time). Nevertheless
column2: we give it a chance. 😇 "302012

3661lenhard1515701closed2018-01-23T15:12:03Z2018-01-24T09:45:12ZExport no empty lines in RIS formatThis fixes the remaining part of #3634
I had a closer look at the export / layout logic and wow
column2: this is arcane! The code is more than 12 years old and almost as bad as the bibtex parser used to be.

column1: This PR is based on two decisions:
- I do not want to change the old layouting code. If I do
column2: I am almost guaranteed to break it in many ways.

column1: - I do not know if the removal of empty lines in exported text is really desirable in all cases. Maybe users wrote their custom formatters to explicitly include empty lines? I cannot tell.
We now have one case (RIS export) where empty lines are not desired. So
column2: I implemented a solution that only changes the behavior of the RIS export
column3: but leaves all others untouched. Nonetheless
column4: it is very easy (single constructor parameter) to let other formats use empty line elimination as well.

column1: The empty line elimination is done using a hardly understandable
column2: but fully functional regex.

3665lenhard1515701closed2018-01-25T13:00:14Z2018-01-31T17:07:12ZMigrate importer tests to JUnit5In the course of https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/3642#issuecomment-358581869 we realized that our current (JUnit4) parameterized tests are not executed on the (JUnit5) travis build. This is tracked here: #3645 I think this is a huge problem
column2: because we are missing out on a lot of validation here.

column1: This PR is a migration of the paramterized RIS tests from JUnit 4 to JUnit 5. I'd like to put this forward to discussion
column2: so that we can agree on how our parameterized JUnit 5 tests are to look like. When we have agreed
column3: we can migrate all tests. So
column4: please look at the code and write if you are happy with this.

column1: [Note that parameters cannot be resolved for lifecycle methods](http://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/user-guide/#writing-tests-parameterized-tests-lifecycle-interop) (`@BeforeEach`) in JUnit 5
column2: hence the structure in the PR.

3666tobiasdiez5037600closed2018-01-26T00:07:55Z2018-01-29T11:59:15ZBring back the context menu<!-- describe the changes you have made here: what
column2: why

column1: before | after

![before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5037600/35418774-988eddda-0234-11e8-9679-28d282f4faca.png) | ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5037600/35418772-96061b00-0234-11e8-8eb4-af8ca98d8a75.png)
Removed a few commands that are not needed often and thus don't need to be placed that prominently.
- Print entry preview: available through entry preview
- All commands related to marking: marking is not yet reimplemented
- Set/clear/append/rename fields: available through Edit menu
- Manage keywords: available through Edit menu
- Copy linked files to folder:  available through File menu
Changes in the architecture:
- Previously
column2: an `Action` defined both the visual properties (text
column3: icons
column4: ...) as well as the behavior. These actions are usually defined in the base panel (or main frame).

column1: - Now the visual elements are defined by an `ActionFX` (to be renamed to `Action` as soon as the old class can be removed) and the behavior by implementing the `Command` interface. This separation makes it possible to reuse the visual aspects without the ties to the behavior.
- In the long term
column2: the commands should be defined outside of the main big classes. This is not done in this PR
column3: because then the scope and size would explode. The extraction is best done peu à peu.

column1: With this PR the main frame is converted to use JavaFX. Thus the role is now inverted and instead of embedding JavaFX in a Swing app
column2: we now embedded the old Swing controls in a real JavaFX app. Hopefully
column3: this leads to less problems.

column2: menu
column3: lila header instead of toolbar). The main reason for putting it out right now is to test if pushing the migration further fixes the issues encountered with Linux and MacOS.

3714lenhard1515701closed2018-02-13T12:11:38Z2018-02-15T08:46:18ZUpdate entry editor when entry type changesFixes an issue partly described here: https://github.com/koppor/jabref/issues/289
So far
column2: changing the type of an entry did not update the type label in the entry editor or the structure of its tabs
column3: which might offer different fields for a different type.

column1: This turns the type attribute of `BibEntry` into a property so that it is possible to listen to this property and to react to changes. It also adds a `ChangeListener` to the `EntryEditor` that updates the label and the contents of the visible tab.
@tobiasdiez It would be cool if you could have a quick look at the listener related stuff to check that I remove it correctly and do not introduce any memory leaks.

column1: Instead of ""marking entries"" to highlight them
column2: the entries in the maintable now have a small colored bar in front of them whose color comes from the first group that matches them (see picture below). For migration
column3: a group is created for every value of the `__markedentry` field and the entry is added to this group.

- Fixed an issue where the default icon of a group was not colored correctly.

column1: This PR removes all the old code related to color customization of the maintable. In principle
column2: it is possible to allow a similar customization also with JavaFX
column3: but it is way easier to let the user switch between themes defined in different css files. The complexity of the current approach is perhaps best illustrated by the huge number of lines which are removed with  this PR. At some point
column4: we should discuss how we facilitate the development / embedding of new themes
column5: but this is not the purpose of this PR.

3839halirutan511683closed2018-03-12T15:11:06Z2018-03-26T21:38:24ZConsistent FX color scheme for JabRefThe PR aims to make the look and feel of JabRef more consistent by providing a well-chosen set of base colors and deriving other colors from it. At the moment
column2: I used a flat and bright scheme with the original JabRef blue as the theme color.

column1: ![scrShot](http://i.imgur.com/kOSJWNW.png)
In addition to the changes in the FX CSS files
column2: I provide an additional true type font for the application icons that are not available in the Material Design Icon set. It can be loaded and used in exactly the same way as the Material Design Icons and only small changes to the code where necessary. As soon as we agreed on using this
column3: I can make further adjustments and additions (currently
column4: WinEd is missing) to the icons so that they fit perfectly into our toolbar. The one-colored icons should represent the original icon as much as possible and should be recognizable. The will look like this

column1: ![i1](https://files.gitter.im/JabRef/jabref/W5wc/Lyx.png) ![i2](https://files.gitter.im/JabRef/jabref/W5wc/Emacs.png) ![i3](https://files.gitter.im/JabRef/jabref/W5wc/arXiv.png) ![i4](https://files.gitter.im/JabRef/jabref/W5wc/OpenOffice.png)
For those who would like to help to work on this:
Our base style is `modena.css` and to make our restyling easy to use and to understand
column2: we should try to redefine the color variables of `modena.css` as much as possible instead of explicitly introducing and using our own variables. This means
column3: don't use explicit color settings in the definition of styles for a control. If it is a commonly used property e.g. the border color
column4: try to find and overwrite the appropriate modena-variable. If you indeed need a specific color
column5: then re-use the ones defined at the top of `Main.css`.

column1: With this PR
column2: working on styling and css files should be easier. Css files are now watched for changes and automatically reloaded. Thus JabRef does not have to be restarted in order to apply a new design. In IntellJ you can now start debugging
column3: edit the css and apply the changes by `Build > Build project` or `Run > Reload Changed Classes`.

column1: The idea of the `ThemeLoader` class is to support external css files (next to the jar file) in the future so that users could change the theme on their own.
I'll add a short note documenting this feature to the wiki after this PR gets merged.

column1: Link issues by using the following pattern: [#333](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/333) or [koppor#49](https://github.com/koppor/jabref/issues/47).

column2: because GitHub does not support autolinking there. -->

column1: Right now it is pretty difficult to create dialogs in JavaFX using FXML. For once
column2: you have to create a bunch of files (fxml
column3: view
column4: controller
column5: view model) and there are huge problems with passing data between the caller and the controller (e.g.
column6: no complex objects
column7: cumbersome injection setup

column1: So I took the opportunity to rewrite parts of the afterburner framework to make the workflow more fluid. With these changes
column2: the view class is merged with the controller and it is very easy to pass data to and from the controller. In particular
column3: the code in https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/3005 should become much simpler.

column1: Moreover
column2: I started to embed the content of a few Swing dialogs (cleanup and preferences) in a JavaFX window. This is kind of proof of concept
column3: works pretty nicely in my opinion and is probably the only way to fix the z-hierarchy issues with the old swing dialogs.

column1: Git is not able to properly sort-out some of the changes (the merge of the view and controller classes) and shows a pretty huge diff. If git gurus like @koppor know a way to fix this
column2: feel free to hijack this PR.

3882stefan-kolb2141507closed2018-03-23T15:15:52Z2018-03-28T15:37:40ZPriority fetcher- all fetchers are run in parallel now
- the result with the highest priority wins
- InterruptedException | ExecutionException | CancellationException ignore is more critical; not sure if the code behaves as we want it everytime
Trust Levels:
- SOURCE (highest)
- PUBLISHER
- PREPRINT
- META_SEARCH
- UNKNOWN
Current trust levels:
- DOI: SOURCE
- ScienceDircect: Publisher
- Springer: Publisher
- ACS: Publisher
- IEEE: Publisher
- Google Scholar: META_SEARCH
- Arxiv: PREPRINT
- OpenAccessDOI: META_SEARCH"326292772419

column1: A bit refactoring around FXML files (see commit messages for details). Most notable change is the introduction of `JabRefIconView` which makes it possible to use the `JabRefIcons` enum in FXML files
column2: which help to have a consistent usage of icons across JabRef.

column1: I tried to implement #3885 but changes of the file type in the linked file editor are not saved for some reason. I'll investigate this again after https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/3005 is merged.
Thus only some relative minor code improvements / fixes:
- Refactor external file type classes and extract a common `ExternalFileType` interface.
- Extract all built-in file types to separate enum (implementing `ExternalFileType`)
- Fix display of External file type editor dialog (which is not shown in the current maintable-beta version)

column1: This PR adds a dark theme. Based on the wonderful work of @halirutan
column2: this was really easy and only a handful of colors had to be changed.

column1: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5037600/37995234-fc2cadcc-3213-11e8-8408-480c70263317.png)
The highlight color is taken from the icon that won the design contest last year. In the end
column2: the dark theme is more a Spielerei from my side to test how nicely the JavaFX styling works and I definitely think we should provide a light theme as the default.

column1: The dark theme was also a nice test because it revealed a few 1-px wide borders
column2: shadows and other small stuff. Based on these discoveries
column3: I also changed the light theme a bit. These changes are just a proposal and are open for discussion. In my opinion
column4: the light theme still needs a bit of love until it is finished (e.g. I find the side pane should be colored in a darker color to better distinguish it from the main table and the background color of the header looks a bit ""dirty"".)

column1: With these changes
column2: the `checkstyle` task is no longer invoked as part of the `build` or `check` task. The `checkstyleMain` task and its variations are kept.

column1: Reason: The build fails as soon as the checkstyle task fails
column2: possibly hiding more important build or test failures (recent [example](https://travis-ci.org/JabRef/jabref/builds/371621951?utm_source=github_status&utm_medium=notification)). Moreover
column3: the checkstyle task is invoked as a separate build command on travis anyway.

column1: fixes #3971
[UI Image of entry type in dropdown](https://github.com/jacksonrya/help.jabref.org/blob/81c1795cfd3b9defc64fd61b71eb85e9e34e7442/en/images/NewEntryChooseType-IDGeneratorHighlighted-Rfc.png)
RFC
column2: an additional ID-based entry generator ID type
column3: has been added in order to fetch more complete BibTeX data compared to DOI fetches of RFC type.

column1: Following the DiVA ID type classes as template
column2: an RFC fetcher class and fetcher test has been added.

column1: I added RFC to the ID-based entry generator list within WebFetchers so it is an option in the dialog's dropdown.
Currently
column2: the RFC fetcher class accepts search requests with or without the ""rfc"" prefix--is this an okay feature?

column1: Additionally
column2: help in finding the best [RFC BibTeX API](https://www.rfc-editor.org/retrieve/). I am using the API referenced in [#3971](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3971).

column1: P.S. This is my first ever contribution to open source
column2: so thanks for your patience... 😄

column1: In [the forum](http://discourse.jabref.org/t/postgresql-connection-jabref-4-0-4-1-4-2/1113)
column2: there were some reports that the postgre SQL integration sometimes fails due to a bug in the sql driver we use. It appears that the driver [pgjdbc-ng](https://github.com/impossibl/pgjdbc-ng) is no longer maintained and all the features we need are present in the [""official driver""](https://github.com/pgjdbc/pgjdbc). Thus I switched to the later in the hope that it fixes the issues mentioned in the forum.

4043koppor1366654closed2018-05-21T11:45:07Z2018-05-23T10:14:37ZAdd ""Add Braces"" Formatter""In the context using Springer's default bst file
column2: the ""title casing"" feature of BibTeX is not desired. When working with persons quickly creating their bibliography
column3: the solution is to put `{}` around the `title` field. Up to now
column4: JabRef supports the inverse feature by the `RemoveBracesFormatter`. This PR adds the `AddBracesFormatter`. I am very aware that the other formatters such as our `org.jabref.logic.formatter.casechanger.ProtectTermsFormatter`. However
column5: that formatter relies on a fixed list of terms
column6: whereas this `AddBracesFormater` ""just works"" (under some assumptions).

4044koppor1366654closed2018-05-21T20:04:57Z2018-05-24T14:56:15ZStreamline formatter implementationThis builds on https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/4043 and streamlines the code of the ""formatter"" framework a bit.
- Introduce AbstractFormatter to ensure that `hashCode` and `equals` are implemented the same way
- Introduce a test to ensure that `getKey()` returns a unique key"516094529
4045koppor1366654closed2018-05-21T20:33:16Z2018-05-25T09:03:36ZAdd NormalizeEnDashesFormatter"Many titles are of the form `Word Word - Subtitle`. However
column2: `-` is the wrong dash. It has to be [en dash](http://www.thepunctuationguide.com/en-dash.html). [It is argued](https://writing.stackexchange.com/a/11018/14570) that it has to be an [em dash](http://www.thepunctuationguide.com/em-dash.html)
column3: but for me an em dash is too long and nearly all persons do not use it.

column1: I discovered a comment at that writing.sx question:
> The Oxford Style Guide actually recommends an en-dash flanked with two spaces over an em-dash and no spaces
![new](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1366654/40328501-e3e96094-5d46-11e8-83ca-d6409707aca3.png)
PR builds on https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/pull/4044

4047johannes-manner30231151closed2018-05-22T08:34:30Z2018-05-24T10:39:04ZA first solution for the cli problem #4038"ExportFactory is not initialized at this execution point...
The printUsage method is used twice. The JabRefCLI prints the usage
column2: if an error occurs during argument parsing and the ArgumentProcessor prints the usage
column3: when --help option is chosen.

column1: I made two solutions for this problem:
- Commit 1: Some sort of a hack to only get the names of the exporters without altering the processing in the main method.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30231151/40351621-2505b92c-5dad-11e8-9c3c-c780ae48f514.png)
- Commit 2: Changed the order of execution in the main method. The argument processor needs the export factory. I don't know
column2: if the processing of the preferences will influence the cli functionality?

column1: (Partly) fixes https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/4025. Right-click on a group no longer focuses that group. It's not perfect since there is no longer feedback on which group the user clicked and the context menu belongs to.

Clicking the disclosure node (the small arrow) still leads to an immediate selection of the group. The selection happens before any events are triggered on the row and thus I'm not able to intercept the selection.

column1: I tried to remove the `System.exit` call so that JabRef shutdown smoothly. However
column2: currently an AWT-thread does not want to exit. In order to solve this problem
column3: I removed most calls that would init the AWT toolkit. This includes:

column1: - Use JavaFX clipboard instead of AWT
- Remove L&F and font customization
Moreover
column2: the Azure telemetry SDK has a bug https://github.com/Microsoft/ApplicationInsights-Java/issues/662 that prevents certain threads from terminating. I added the workaround mentioned in this issue.

column1: Fixes #3805. Now commands terminated by a hyphen (like `\edition-`) work correctly.
Way back in 2011
column2: Morten added the extra check for hyphens (commit 392bc7a6dd215eb23766378aa90e3995d0847bb7). However
column3: I'm not aware of any field that has a dash in it
column4: so I'm not sure what was the reason for the change (I couldn't find an old bug report).

column2: where we research on generalized architectural decision records (see <https://github.com/adr/gadr-java>) and concrete architectural decision records (see [MADR](https://adr.github.io/madr/)).

column1: We aim for having two ADRs for build tools. One for Maven (see [ADR-0023](https://github.com/eclipse/winery/blob/master/docs/adr/0023-use-maven-as-build-tool.md) at Eclipse Winery) and one for Gradle. The one for gradle is contained in this PR."0061012

column1: Converts the ACM fetcher to the new infrastructure and deletes a lot of gui code that is now no longer needed. Notable changes:
- Fetcher no longer visits each citation page separately but uses the batch export provided by ACM
- Fetcher always queries the full ACM Guide to Computing Literature (previously there was also the option to use the ACM Full-Text collection
column2: which is however completely contained in the former).

column1: - Abstracts are no longer returned (they are simply not exported by ACM)
- All fetcher now use the class `URLDownload` to make the request
column2: and thereby pretend to be Firefox (otherwise we were blocked by ACM). I remember I had a discussion with @stefan-kolb recently about this
column3: but don't remember the outcome.

This removes `AbstractWorker` completely (where Spin was mainly used). All `AbstractWorker`s were
migrated to `BaseAction` using `BackgroundTask`s. This also simplifies `BasePanel` at some points.
Most workers could easily be wrapped in a `BackgroundTask`
column2: as all they do on the UI Thread is call `JabRefFrame.output("".."")` which is already executed on the UI Thread internally.

column1: Some workers were joined with their corresponding actions as all the actions did
column2: was calling the workers.

column1: Add a small script that removes merged branches. Normally
column2: git provides a few commands that detect merged branches (`git branches --merged`) and deletes obsolete ones (`git prune`). However
column3: these commands do not work for PRs that were squashed.

column1: The script below goes through all github PR's and deletes the corresponding local branches if the PR was merged.

After looking at the JSON response of some queries it appears that these cleanups are no longer necessary.

4163florian-beetz8899552closed2018-07-03T20:59:55Z2019-04-30T19:06:45Z[WIP] Cleanup build scriptThis prepares for splitting JabRef into several modules.
The dependencies were extracted to a separate file. This makes it much easier in the future to define shared dependencies across multiple modules
column2: without duplicating them in the build scripts and especially keeping them all updated to the same version.

column1: According to Gradle's guide on [writing maintainable build scripts](https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/authoring_maintainable_build_scripts.html)
column2: build scripts should not contain any imperative logic but just declarative language elements. Imperative logic should live as plugins in the `buildSrc` directory. So I extracted the ANTLR tasks to this directory. This also makes it much easier to move the tasks to another module in the future.

column1: What do you think? I would like to extract the XJC-

column3: and localization-tasks to separate plugins if you approve these changes.

column1: Rewrite web search pane in JavaFX
column2: with the aim to fix https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/4132.

column1: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5037600/42726275-104cd416-8792-11e8-9f48-5fc99882364d.png)
(Still does not a win a prize of great ui design - e.g. the search button should be displayed as a real button; to be improved in further PRs)
Notable other changes:
- Remove all remnants of the old fetcher infrastructure (yeah!)
- Slightly improve command line output when using the `-f` (fetcher) option
- Enable web search and groups pane by default
- Fix bug where web search pane was not shown at start if it was active in last session

4232JoKalliauer15687581closed2018-07-24T09:59:02Z2018-12-29T13:07:38ZNameChange and update to JabRef41) The name has to be changed because otherwise on Ubuntu it will appear twice in activities: once the icon added to favourites and once the opened instance
column2: see https://unix.stackexchange.com/a/59654/241592 for details. The name has to be identical with the Application.

column1: 2) Since Ubuntu 18.04 uses JabRef3
column2: which ruins the grouping of JabRef4
column3: just by starting JabRef! (automatic opening last files and autosave?!?)
column4: you should use JabRef4 using java -jar ~/${[[:Folder To Your Jabref:]]}/JabRef-4.3.1.jar

column1: For more details see (Only for the germans developers): https://wiki.ubuntuusers.de/JabRef/ (which should be updated (I think that's the first place to search for Germanspeakings)
column2: it says the newest 2.9 version can be installed using sourceforge
column3: maybe you should refer to http://help.jabref.org/en/Installation
column4: which might also should be updated to Ubuntu 18.04.)

column1: 3) The icon does not work
You might should specify that it should be downloaded from:
https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/master/src/main/resources/images/external/JabRef-icon-128.png
and should be stored f.e. in ~/.local/share/icons/

4246upupming24741764closed2018-08-02T12:47:20Z2018-08-03T10:06:58ZSolved #3823 File annotationThis pull request solved #3823
column2: and improved the new line remover.

column1: # Removed hyphens and newlines of highlighted text
I removed all new lines which **don't have preceded `.` or `:`** becaues I think `.` or `:` is often used to start a new paragraph.
Test text:
Test result:
There is another problem with the regular expression `(\r?\n|\r)` when I try to use `(?<![.|:])(\r?\n|\r)` for excluding the new line end with `.` or `:`.
If it's on Windows
column2: the `\r\n` will be replaced with a whitespace
column3: and it is OK. However if we encounter `.\r\n`
column4: the `.\r` will be reserved and the `\n` will be replaced by a whitespace. In this way
column5: the `.\r` will not be shown as new line int the field
column6: and we don't need this whitespace. So instead we should change `.\r\n` to `\r\n` directly.

column1: So I use java's `%n` to distinguish new line wisely.

column2: change case

column1: ![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36831746/43885542-c2fe8826-9beb-11e8-9814-250861513426.png)

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36831746/43885580-e411765e-9beb-11e8-99b2-6a8756bf0cd1.png)

I am looking forward to your feedback.

column1: [#3959](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/3959)
We migrate some packages imported from JUnit4 to JUnit5
column2: such as org.junit.Test --> org.junit.jupiter.api.Test
column3: org.junit.experimental.categories.Category --> org.junit.jupiter.api.Tag
column4: and so on.

column1: At the same time
column2: we slightly modify some codes which rely on those packages and doesn't apply to JUnit5 but applys to JUnit4. For example
column3: we change @Test(excepted = XXX.class) into using assertThrows and lambda
column4: @Category(XXX.class) into @Tag(“XXX”)
column5: @Before into @BeforeEach
column6: and so on.

column1: Hi
column2: I'm trying to fix the issue #3959
column3: and I have some problems here. Can someone help me?

column1: **1. Some tests don't seem to have a parameter source**
Such as  `BibTeXMLExporterTest.java`
column2: `MSBibExportFormatTestFiles.java`
column3: `ModsExportFormatTestFiles.java`
column4: and so on. Since I can't get feedback from both Travis CI and my IDE
column5: I couldn't do anything at the moment.

column1: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25541992/43997706-ee482a88-9e15-11e8-9b43-9b9f9853c150.png)
**2. Something about the external libraries**
For `MainArchitectureTestsWithArchUnit.java`
`testCompile 'com.tngtech.archunit:archunit-junit:0.8.3'` **isn't enough for migrate this test to JUnit 5.**
Just a few days ago
column2: `ArchUnit` just supported tests with only JUnit 5 package. But this feature needs a `testCompile 'com.tngtech.archunit:archunit-junit:0.9.0` and as far as I know
column3: this version has not been released yet.

column1: For `CiteKeyBasedFileFinderTest.java`
column2: I haven't found an extension in JUnit 5 for the `MockitoJUnitRunner.class` in JUnit 4. And it seems that their (mock) official version hasn't been release yet
column3: too.

column1: **3. The Database Test**
As I can see
column2: those tests have already been migrated partly to JUnit 5. But the rest of it is the PROBLEM.

column1: I've tried to migrate `DBMSProcessorTest.java`
column2: but the code is no longer concise after that.

column1: For example
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25541992/43997780-26078368-9e18-11e8-9fce-43d293fedf88.png)
this is the old version
column2: and

column1: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25541992/43997784-3e0ae356-9e18-11e8-8073-d43eeb12f0d5.png)
that is the new version. And that is only part of it.
The reason is that I couldn't pass the parameters to the `@BeforeEach` method in JUnit 5
column2: but JUnit 4 can use those local variable to pass the parameters. I think this is where the difference occurred.

column1: **4. The GUI Test**
I just change the `@Category` annotation to `@Tag` annotation
column2: as I have known that those tests are mostly obsolete.

column1: **5. About CleanupWorkerTest**
This test is not hard to migrate from JUnit 4 to 5. But when I finish
column2: and run the tests on my IDE
column3: two tests failed. And the error message is quite weird. It seems that the worker doesn't work in JUnit 5 tests.

column1: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25541992/43997847-be8c685a-9e19-11e8-9c3a-a911d9daeafe.png)
And if there are any errors or something can be improved in other tests that I didn't mention
column2: please let me know! Thanks!

4274NorwayMaple21989062closed2018-08-17T15:41:26Z2018-08-18T11:42:19ZPin errorprone dependency to specific versionI pinned an errorprone dependency to version 2.3.1
column2: which is the latest version as of August 17
column3: 2018.  As it stands in the master branch
column4: the plugin net.ltgt.errorprone creates a configuration of errorprone that automatically updates to the latest version
column5: which is meant to be overridden.  I overrode that configuration by explicitly creating it in build.grade
column6: and then I added the dependency to the configuration necessary to pin the version.  build.gradle executes the plugins first
column7: but then overrides the configuration afterward.  The issue is [#4176](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/4176).

I originally had this in the cleanupSingleString method to prevent KEY_FIELD from being cleaned up (reformatted) entirely
column2: but decided to let the user specifically format that field.  When the user chooses to format all fields at once
column3: however
column4: the KEY_FIELD will be not be reformatted. This solves issue [#4148](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/4148)

column1: This is a complete rework of the file writing logic. Since this is the most essential part of JabRef
column2: I would kindly ask to every @JabRef/developers to have a look at the code (at least on the new `AtomicOutputStream` which does the hard work).

column1: The new strategy for saving the bib file is as follows:
- Create a backup (with .bak suffix) of the original file in the same directory as the destination file (if set in preferences).
- Write to a temporary file (with .tmp suffix) in the same directory.
- Create a save-backup (with .sav suffix) of the original file (if it exists) in the same directory.
- Move the temporary file to the correct place
column2: overwriting any file that already exists at that location.

column1: - Delete the save-backup file.
What is not clear to me is how one should handle (almost) concurrent saving processes of different users to the same file. Is it enough to lock a file (`nio.FileLock`) and if yes
column2: which (the tmp?)?

The underlying problem is the same as in #4152
However
column2: I came up with a workaround for MSOffice.

column1: 1. Getting the original field
2. Check for corporate author (braces start and end)
3. get latex free value
4. Readd braces for corporate
5. Parse author
The only edgecase which can occur if the entry starts with an author in latex braces and ends with an author in latex braces. That one will probably be interpreted as corporate.

column1: Potential fix for [#4306](https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/4306).
The method ``performNameConflictCheck`` added in ``LinkedFileViewModel`` helps check whether or not the filename is already equal to the suggested filename. If so
column2: it returns true
column3: otherwise
column4: it returns false. This method is then called in ``LinkedFilesEditor`` during ``createContextMenuForFile()`` to decide whether or not the Rename
column5: Move
column6: or Rename and Move menu options are to be disabled.

column1: The method itself works as I tested it by running the code live with the JVM. Having the filename == suggested filename indeed disabled those three menu options in the context menu. The issue however
column2: is that I'm having trouble writing my test case for it. I'm running into a couple of nullpointers being thrown when I try to run my test case ``checkNameConflict()`` in ``LinkedFileViewModelTest``. Specifically
column3: it reports that there are nullpointers when accessing the ``getSuggestedFilename()`` called in within ``checkNameConflict`` in the ``LinkedFileViewModel`` class.

- Mr. DLib now provides recommendations in JSON
- JabRef presents these using JavaFX
- In line with GDPR

column1: - Included a new setting in Entry Editor Preferences to allow users to retract their consent for the above
- Removed setting of html_representation field for recommendations - UI is now populated from the data fields themselves.
- Changed the default color of JavaFX Hyperlinks to '-jr-theme'
Note:
The Mr. DLib Dev environment - used for JabRef Dev versions - is quite a bit slower than the production environment.

column1: e83680f18d815ebebc779d239a6eacd8930150fe changed the way the SaveOrderConfig works. These changes caused SaveOrderConfigDisplay to throw IndexOutOfBoundsExceptions when saving the settings. This pull request fixes that issue.
Additionally the RadioButtons allowed the user to select none or multiple order types. This pull request adds them to a ToggleGroup
column2: which prevents these multiselections.

column1: The new way of working is through `ActionFactory` which uses `setGraphic()` instead:
private static void setGraphic(MenuItem node
column2: Action action) {

column1: node.graphicProperty().unbind();
action.getIcon().ifPresent(icon -> node.setGraphic(icon.getGraphicNode()));
Since the only composite icons are the ones used for rank
column2: using the full `unicode` field of `Node` instead of only the unicode of the first icon won't affect other Actions.

column1: @Override
public Node getGraphicNode() {
GlyphIcons icon = icons.get(0);
Text text = new Text(icon.unicode()); //Replaced with unicode
text.getStyleClass().add(""glyph-icon"");
text.setStyle(String.format(""-fx-font-family: %s;""
column2: icon.fontFamily()));

column1: color.ifPresent(color -> text.setStyle(text.getStyle() + String.format(""-fx-fill: %s;""
column2: ColorUtil.toRGBCode(color))));

column1: return text;
